But the opposition says the price hike will hit the poor hardest.

Indonesia is a major oil producer, but it still has to import much of its fuel.

The government has been subsidising fuel for years, but the cost has become unsustainable in recent months as oil prices have risen to record highs.

Labour's four little words

The four words that have haunted Labour since the election - "for the many, not the few" - are now being deployed against the party by the Conservatives.

Theresa May used her conference speech to say that Labour was now the "anti-business party" and to accuse it of being "divided, dysfunctional and all-out hostile to business".

She said businesses were "asking themselves whether Labour is still the party of aspiration and enterprise, or whether it has become the party of resistance and resentment".

And she warned that a Labour government would be "a threat to the future of this country".

It was a clear attempt to paint Labour as the party of the past, while positioning the Tories as the party of the future.

Mrs May also sought to use Brexit to further wedge Labour, saying that while her party was "working to make a success of Brexit", Labour was "plotted against it".

It is a line of attack that is likely to become increasingly common in the months ahead.

Labour has sought to quell talk of a feud between two of its most senior figures, after a leaked letter revealed a split.

The letter, from shadow chancellor John McDonnell to Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, was critical of Mr Corbyn's handling of the economy.

In it, Mr McDonnell said he had been "left in the dark" over economic policy and accused Mr Corbyn of a "lack of consultation and transparency".

But a Labour spokesman said the two men were "working together closely".

The letter was leaked to the BBC's political editor Laura Kuenssberg.

In it, Mr McDonnell said he was "disappointed" that he had not been consulted on Mr Corbyn's decision to appoint a new economics adviser, James Meadway.

He also accused Mr Corbyn of a "lack of consultation and transparency" over economic policy, and said there was a "worrying lack of clarity" about Labour's approach.

The letter was dated 28 September, but it is not clear when it was sent.

A Labour spokesman said: "Jeremy and John are working together closely on Labour's alternative plan for the economy, which will be set out in detail at our party conference later this month."

The BBC's political editor said the letter was "significant" because it showed the depth of the disagreement between the two men.

She said the letter was likely to fuel speculation about a leadership challenge to Mr Corbyn.

Wal-Mart has hit back at accusations that it mistreats its workers in the US, saying it offers "competitive" wages and benefits.

The world's largest retailer was responding to a report by the National Employment Law Project (NELP), which claimed that Wal-Mart employees were paid less than workers at other firms.

Wal-Mart said the NELP was "biased" and that its report was "inaccurate".

The NELP report said that Wal-Mart workers earned on average $8.81 (5.50) an hour, compared with $9.68 at other firms.

It also claimed that Wal-Mart employees were more likely to be on food stamps and other forms of government assistance than workers at other firms.

But Wal-Mart said the NELP was "funded by unions and other groups that have been critical of our company for many years".

"We are proud of the opportunities we provide our more than one million US associates," said Wal-Mart spokesman Kory Lundberg.

"We offer competitive wages and benefits, and our average full-time hourly wage is more than $11 an hour."

The NELP report comes as Wal-Mart is facing increasing scrutiny over its labour practices.

Earlier this month, a group of US lawmakers accused the firm of "systematically" violating labour laws.

And last week, a group of current and former Wal-Mart employees filed a lawsuit against the company, alleging that it had discriminated against women.

"United are now nine points behind leaders Chelsea after a comfortable victory over City at the Etihad.

"Ander Herrera scored the opener against the run of play when he converted Antonio Valencia's cross after 18 minutes.

"City were caught cold again early in the second half when Marcus Rashford ran on to Herrera's pass and slotted past Claudio Bravo.

"Pep Guardiola's side applied some late pressure but failed to breach a resolute United defence."

Councils in England and Wales are preparing to set their budgets for the upcoming financial year, with many expected to raise council tax.

The average band D council tax bill in England is currently 1,671, but this is set to rise by an average of 107, or 6.5%, in the next financial year, according to a survey by the Local Government Association (LGA).

The LGA said the tax rises were necessary to help plug a "financial black hole" of 5.8bn in council budgets.

The government has said it will provide councils with an extra 1.3bn to help them cope with the "challenges" of the pandemic.

But the LGA said this would not be enough to cover the extra costs councils have faced, such as providing extra support to vulnerable residents and providing PPE for staff.

Councils in Wales will also be setting their budgets for the next financial year, with many expected to raise council tax.

The Welsh Government has said it will provide an extra 200m to help councils cope with the "financial challenges" of the pandemic.

Venus Williams was stunned in the second round of the French Open by unseeded Italian Sara Errani.

The American, seeded 10th, lost 6-0 7-6 (7-5) to the world number 29 in Paris.

It is the first time Williams has failed to win a set in the opening two rounds of a grand slam since the 1999 US Open.

The 32-year-old had been in good form on clay this season, reaching the final in Madrid.

But she was well below her best against Errani, who will face either Maria Sharapova or Tsvetana Pironkova in the third round.

"I'm just really disappointed," said Williams. "I felt like I could have done better.

"I made too many errors. I was just off. I couldn't find my rhythm. I made a lot of unforced errors."

Williams had won both of her previous meetings with Errani, but the Italian took control from the start, breaking the American's serve in the opening game.

The second set was a closer affair, with Williams saving two set points at 5-6 down, but she was unable to take the match into a decider.

"I'm just really disappointed," said Williams. "I felt like I could have done better.

"I made too many errors. I was just off. I couldn't find my rhythm. I made a lot of unforced errors."

Williams had won both of her previous meetings with Errani, but the Italian took control from the start, breaking the American's serve in the opening game.

The second set was a closer affair, with Williams saving two set points at 5-6 down, but she was unable to take the match into a decider.

The United States has issued a travel ban on the two Guantanamo detainees who were released to Slovakia on Monday.

The US State Department said the men - Ahmed Bilal and Muhamad Naim - were not permitted to travel to the US.

It is unclear if the travel ban will apply to any other countries.

Both men were cleared for release in 2009 but it took years for a country to agree to take them in.

They are the first of 104 detainees remaining at Guantanamo to be transferred under President Barack Obama.

Mr Obama has vowed to close the detention centre by the end of his term in office but faces significant obstacles.

The State Department said the travel ban was in accordance with US law.

"The United States has issued travel bans for both of the individuals who were transferred from Guantanamo Bay on Monday to Slovakia," a spokesman said.

"This is in accordance with US law, which requires that the secretary of state ban the entry of any individual who, after their transfer, is reasonably believed to pose a threat to the United States, its citizens, or its interests."

 Slovakia's Interior Ministry said the men were not currently planning to travel to the US.

"We have been informed about the US decision by the US embassy in Slovakia," a spokeswoman told the AFP news agency.

"The men have not expressed any interest in travelling to the United States."

Bilal and Naim are the first of 104 detainees remaining at Guantanamo to be transferred under President Barack Obama.

Mr Obama has vowed to close the detention centre by the end of his term in office but faces significant obstacles.

The Liberal Democrats are to pledge to scrap stamp duty on homes worth up to 300,000 as part of their general election campaign.

The party will also commit to building 300,000 homes a year and reforming the planning system.

It comes as the Lib Dems launch their manifesto, which they say is "fully costed" and would see 50bn extra spent on public services.

The party is also pledging to legalise cannabis, invest in mental health services and plant 60 million trees a year.

On Brexit, the Lib Dems say they would give the public the final say on any deal, with the option to remain in the EU.

The party is also pledging to invest 130bn in tackling climate change, and to introduce a "circular economy" - where waste is reduced and resources reused.

The Lib Dems are currently polling at around 15%, and are hoping to make gains from both the Conservatives and Labour.

The party is targeting Remain voters who are unhappy with the way the Brexit negotiations are going, as well as those who want to see more investment in public services.

The manifesto launch comes as the Lib Dems face criticism from some quarters for their decision to form a coalition government with the Conservatives in 2010.

The party's then-leader Nick Clegg apologised for breaking a key election promise not to raise university tuition fees, and the party was widely seen to have been damaged by the experience.

However, Lib Dem leader Vince Cable has said the party has "learned lessons" from the coalition years and is now in a "stronger position" to offer a "credible" alternative to the Conservatives and Labour.

Your mobile phone could become your own personal karaoke machine, if the latest idea from Japanese technology giant NEC takes off.

The firm has filed a patent application in the US for a system that would let people download music and lyrics onto their handsets.

Then, by pointing the phone at a microphone, they could sing along to the backing track.

The technology would be able to correct the singer's pitch, so even those who are tone deaf could stay in tune.

It is not the first time NEC has come up with an unusual use for a mobile phone.

Earlier this year, it unveiled a handset that could be used as a credit card.

"There is no scope for a fresh start on European plans for a single patent law, the European Commission has said.

It was responding to calls from industry experts for the proposals to be redrawn following their rejection by the European Parliament last week.

But the Commission said the project had been too long in the making to be abandoned now.

It is confident that a deal can still be reached with the parliament.

Last week, the parliament voted by a small margin against the draft legislation, which would have created a single EU patent and a court to adjudicate on disputes.

MEPs were concerned that the court would be based in Luxembourg, rather than in another EU country.

They were also worried about the language the patent would be written in - currently, it would have to be in English, French or German, but not all MEPs are happy with that.

'Good step'

Responding to the vote, Martin Selmayr, spokesperson for Internal Market Commissioner Michel Barnier, said the project had been in the works for decades and it was crucial that it be completed.

"We need to find an agreement with the European Parliament as soon as possible so that the EU can have a single patent area," he said.

"This is a good step for the EU economy, for jobs, for citizens, for patients."

There had been calls from some industry experts for the proposals to be redrawn, but the Commission has now ruled that out.

A spokesman said the proposals were the result of years of negotiations and it was not possible to start from scratch.

But he said the Commission was confident that a compromise could be reached with the parliament.

The two sides will now hold further talks in an attempt to break the impasse."

The Sound of Music is coming home.

The film, which was based on the true story of the von Trapp family singers, will be screened at the Salzburg Festival in Austria next year.

The Sound of Music was shot on location in Salzburg in 1964, and the city has been home to the von Trapps since they fled Austria during World War Two.

The screening will be held on the fifty-fifth anniversary of the film's release, on July 20, 2019.

Halo 2, the Xbox-exclusive first-person shooter, has sold five million copies worldwide since its release last November, according to its manufacturer Microsoft.

The game has been a massive success for the US software giant, helping to boost sales of its Xbox console.

Halo 2 is the sequel to the hugely popular Halo: Combat Evolved, which was released in 2001.

Microsoft said that in the US alone, Halo 2 had generated $125m (68m) in sales within the first 24 hours of its release.

The game has also been a hit with critics, with many lauding its graphics and gameplay.

The family of murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence have called for a review of the sentence given to one of his killers.

Gary Dobson was jailed for life in 2012 after being found guilty of Stephen's murder, 18 years after the attack.

His co-defendant David Norris was also jailed for life but had his conviction overturned on appeal in 2013.

In a letter to the attorney general, Stephen's mother Doreen Lawrence said Dobson's sentence should be increased.

"I am writing to request that you review the sentence of Gary Dobson in relation to the murder of my son Stephen Lawrence," she said.

"I believe that the sentence was unduly lenient and does not reflect the seriousness of the crime."

Stephen, 18, was stabbed to death in a racist attack by a gang of white youths in Eltham, south-east London, in 1993.

Dobson, 36, and Norris, 35, were both found guilty of murder at the Old Bailey in 2012 after a re-examination of evidence.

Norris' conviction was later quashed by the Court of Appeal and he was released from prison.

Dobson was given a minimum term of 15 years and two months in prison, meaning he could be eligible for parole in 2028.

In her letter, Mrs Lawrence said she was "extremely disappointed" with the sentence given to Dobson.

"I believe that the starting point for his sentence should have been 30 years, which would have been in line with the sentence given to David Norris," she said.

"I would also ask that you review the parole board's decision to release Gary Dobson in 2028.

"I do not believe that he should be released until he has served a minimum of 25 years in prison."

The attorney general's office said it would consider the request but stressed that it was "very rare" for sentences to be increased.

The Conservatives are to pledge to scrap 700 quangos to save jobs and money if they win the next election.

The party says unnecessary agencies are taking up space in government buildings and waste money on duplication.

It has drawn up a list of 29 bodies to abolish outright and plans to carry out a review of the rest.

Labour says the Tories' plans are riddled with errors and their numbers do not add up.

The Conservatives say the 29 bodies slated for abolition will save 1.35bn over four years and help protectfrontline jobs and services.

They include the Grain Marketing Board, the British Film Council, the Health Protection Agency and the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency.

The party also plans to scrap the Child Maintenance and Enforcement Commission and replace it with a "simpler and more cost-effective" system.

A further 30 agencies are to be merged or have their functions transferred to other bodies, including the Serious Fraud Office and the Equality and Human Rights Commission.

The Tories say a further 360 will be subject to a "zero-based review" to assess whether they are " providing value for money" and their functions could be carried out more effectively elsewhere.

Foxx and Swank win US awards

Hollywood stars Jamie Foxx and Hilary Swank have been named best actor and actress at the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) Awards in Los Angeles.

Foxx, who won an Oscar for his role in Ray, was honoured for his performance in Collateral.

Swank, who has already won a Golden Globe and a Critics' Choice Award for Million Dollar Baby, dedicated her award to co-star Clint Eastwood.

"I share this completely with you," she told him.

The two actors were among the favourites to win Oscars at the ceremony in Hollywood on 27 February.

'Humbling experience'

Foxx, who plays a taxi driver caught up in a night of violence in Collateral, said it was "a humbling experience" to be recognised by his peers.

"I'm just happy to be here," he said. "I'm just happy to be working."

Swank, who plays a determined boxer in Million Dollar Baby, said she was "absolutely thrilled" to win the award.

"I'm so proud to be a part of this film," she said.

"I'm so proud of our director, our producer, our writer and our cast."

The SAG Awards are seen as a key indicator of success at the Oscars, with many of the same actors nominated for both prizes.

Last year, Sean Penn and Charlize Theron won the best actor and actress prizes at the SAG Awards and went on to win Oscars.

Ocean's Twelve has raced to the top of the US box office on its opening weekend.

The all-star sequel, featuring George Clooney, Brad Pitt and Julia Roberts, took $39.2m (21.5m).

It knocked last week's number one film, The Polar Express, starring Tom Hanks, into second place with takings of $23.3m (13.026m).

Another new entry, Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, was third with $12.7m (7.1m).

The weekend's other new releases fared less well. Alexander, Oliver Stone's historical epic starring Colin Farrell, opened in fifth place with $11.3m (6.34m).

The government has rejected a Lords report which says the detention of terror suspects without charge for up to 42 days is "unacceptable in a democratic society".

Home Secretary Jacqui Smith said the report was "flawed" and the government would not be changing its plans.

The peers said the government had failed to make a case for the extension.

They also said the government had "rushed" the legislation through Parliament.

The government has said it needs the extra time to question suspects in cases where there is a large amount of material to go through, or where police need to follow a complex trail of evidence.

But the peers said the government had failed to make a case for the extension and that the 42-day limit should only be used in "exceptional circumstances".

The report also said the government had "rushed" the legislation through Parliament without proper scrutiny.

Ms Smith said the government would "robustly" defend the legislation in the House of Lords.

The government is expected to try to overturn the peers' amendment when the bill returns to the Commons.

The comedy Meet the Fockers has kept its lead at the US box office for a second weekend, taking $26.5m (14.3m).

The film, which stars Ben Stiller and Robert De Niro, was closely followed by The Aviator, which took $25.6m (13.9m).

The Polar Express, starring Tom Hanks, was in third place with $22.2m (12.1m).

The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie was in fourth place with $16.1m (8.8m), while National Treasure was in fifth with $15.5m (8.5m).

The top five was rounded out by The Incredibles, which took $11.5m (6.3m).

A banker who claimed her employers subject her to "relentless sexism" has lost her claim.

In a ruling at London's Central Employment Tribunal, Judge Simon L gang said Rebecca Sahota had not been treated less favourably than her male colleagues.

Ms Sahota, who worked for RBS and then Royal Bank of Scotland International (RBSI), accused the banks of a " boys' club" culture.

The banks denied the allegations.

Ms Sahota, who is in her early 30s, began working for RBS in 2006 and transferred to RBSI in 2012.

She claimed that, during her time at the banks, she was passed over for promotion, paid less than her male colleagues and subjected to "humiliating and unwelcome comments" about her appearance.

In his ruling, Judge gang said that, while there was "some evidence" of sexism at RBSI, Ms Sahota had not been treated less favourably than her male colleagues.

He added that the banks had "legitimate reasons" for the decisions they had made regarding her pay and promotion.

Ms Sahota said she was "disappointed" by the ruling and was considering her options.

Quentin Tarantino has he will make a sequel to the 1995 cult classic Friday.

In an interview with Entertainment Weekly, the director said: "We're pretty serious about it."

He added that the script was "pretty much done".

Tarantino co-wrote the original movie, which starred Ice Cube and Chris Tucker, about two stoners who spend a day trying to buy cannabis.

It spawned a 2002 sequel, Friday After Next, which was directed by Steve Carr.

Tarantino said: "The idea is to have Cube and Tucker back. It would be a straight-up sequel with Cube and Tucker."

The film-maker, who is currently promoting new film Django Unchained, also revealed he had discussed the possibility of making a fourth instalment of Kill Bill with Uma Thurman.

He said: "I just started thinking about it recently. Should I do a movie like that again? I loved making that movie."

Thurman played the lead role of The Bride in the two-part martial arts movie, which was released in 2003 and 2004.

Two US men who ran a popular online piracy site have been convicted of conspiracy and copyright infringement.

Jeremy Aures and Jesse Terrell ran TVShack.net, which provided links to illegal copies of TV shows and movies.

They were convicted by a federal jury in North Carolina after a five-day trial.

Aures and Terrell now face up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine when they are sentenced in March.

US prosecutors said TVShack.net had more than seven million unique visitors in 2010 and earned advertising revenue of at least $150,000 (93,000).

The website allowed users to find illegal copies of TV shows and movies that had been uploaded to file-sharing sites such as MegaUpload.

"The defendants knowingly profited from massive online piracy, costing copyright holders millions of dollars," said US Assistant Attorney General Lanny Breuer.

"This prosecution sends a strong message that the Justice Department will hold accountable those who unlawfully profit from the creative efforts of others."

Aures' lawyer, Richard Levitt, said his client was "disappointed" with the verdict and would appeal.

"We think the government's case was overstated and that the defendants' actions were less culpable than the government alleged," he said.

Terrell's lawyer, Michael DiLauro, said he was "surprised and disappointed" by the jury's decision.

The US government has been cracking down on online piracy in recent years.

In January 2012, the Department of Justice shut down the file-sharing site MegaUpload and indicted its founder, Kim Dotcom, on racketeering and copyright infringement charges.

Drinks giant Pernod Ricard has agreed to sell its struggling US business, which includes the Lacroix sparkling water brand, to National Beverage for $250m (188m).

Pernod said the deal would help it focus on its "global premium portfolio". It comes after the French company announced job cuts and writedowns last year.

National Beverage is known for its energy drink LaCroix Sparkling Water.

The US company said the deal was part of its plan to expand its "niche beverage" portfolio.

"This transaction is consistent with our strategy to opportunistically add unique assets that fit our culture,

British tennis needs a "rallying cry" to inspire a new generation of players, says three-time Wimbledon champion Jimmy Connors.

The American, who also won eight Grand Slam singles titles, believes the UK is "underachieving" and has urged the Lawn Tennis Association to do more.

"I think British tennis is at a crossroads," Connors, 64, told BBC Sport.

"It needs a rallying cry, it needs an identity. I don't think the LTA is doing enough."

Connors, who was speaking at an event to promote his new autobiography, The Outsider, added: "I think the LTA is way behind in their thinking.

"I don't see any real plan as to how they're going to produce the next great British player. I think they're just hoping it's going to happen."

Britain has not had a men's singles Grand Slam champion since Fred Perry in 1936 and the last woman to win a major was Virginia Wade, who triumphed at Wimbledon in 1977.

There are currently no British players in the world's top 50 and Andy Murray is the only Briton in the men's top 100.

"I think the LTA is doing a lot of things, but are they the right things? I'm not so sure," said Connors.

"I think they're way behind in their thinking. I don't see any real plan as to how they're going to produce the next great British player.

"I think they're just hoping it's going to happen."

Connors believes the UK is "underachieving" in tennis and has urged the Lawn Tennis Association to do more to inspire a new generation of players.

"I think British tennis is at a crossroads," Connors, 64, told BBC Sport.

Broadband fuels online expression

The internet is increasingly being used as a platform for self-expression, with people using social media and blogs to share their views, a report has found.

The study, by the Pew Research Center's Internet and American Life Project, found that 61% of internet users had posted their own photos or videos online.

And nearly half of internet users had commented on someone else's photos or videos.

The report also found that people were using the internet to share their views on politics and current affairs.

Some 42% of internet users had posted their own views on these topics, and 37% had commented on someone else's views.

The report said the findings showed that the internet was "fueling the expression of opinions and views on a variety of topics".

It added that the internet was also "enabling Americans to connect with like-minded people and to find information and opinions that reaffirm their own beliefs".

A film about the life of Dutch artist Vincent van Gogh has been withdrawn from a film festival in the Netherlands after complaints from the artist's descendants.

The film, Loving Vincent, was due to be screened at the Rotterdam Film Festival next month.

But a lawyer representing the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam said the film's makers had not sought permission to use the artist's work.

The museum said it was "disappointed" the film would not be shown.

Loving Vincent, which is due to be released in the UK later this year, is the world's first fully painted feature film.

More than 65,000 individual paintings were used to create the film, which tells the story of the artist's life through the people who knew him.

The lawyer representing the Van Gogh Museum, Menno Fitski, said the filmmakers had not sought permission to use the artist's work, as is required by Dutch law.

"The museum is disappointed that the film will not be shown at the festival," a spokesperson said.

"We would have liked to have seen the film and to have had a dialogue with the filmmakers about the use of Van Gogh's work."

The filmmakers said they were "surprised and disappointed" by the museum's reaction.

"We have been in close contact with the Van Gogh Museum throughout the production of Loving Vincent and they have been kept up-to-date with our progress," they said in a statement.

"We are surprised and disappointed by their reaction to the news that the film will be screened at the Rotterdam Film Festival."

The boss of Worldcom, the telecoms giant at the centre of an accounting scandal, has told a US court he knew nothing about the manipulation of the company's books.

Bernie Ebbers, who resigned as chief executive last month, said he had left the day-to-day running of the business to others.

He was testifying at a hearing in New York to decide whether he should be granted bail while awaiting trial on fraud charges.

Prosecutors say Mr Ebbers should not be freed because he is a flight risk.

But his defence team say he is not a danger to the community and should be allowed to await trial at home with his family.

'No role'

Mr Ebbers is accused of conspiracy and securities fraud in connection with an alleged $11bn (6.4bn) accounting scandal at Worldcom.

He has pleaded not guilty to the charges.

In his testimony, Mr Ebbers said he had delegated authority to chief financial officer Scott Sullivan and other executives and had not been involved in the details of the company's finances.

"I had no role whatsoever in the preparation of the accounting," he said.

"I relied on the people that reported to me to give me accurate information."

Mr Ebbers also said he had not been aware that Worldcom was using "accounting gimmicks" to inflate its profits.

"I was shocked and disappointed when I learned of the accounting irregularities," he said.

'Flight risk'

Prosecutors say Mr Ebbers should not be granted bail because he is a flight risk.

They say he has access to large amounts of cash and has close ties to Canada, where he has a home.

But defence lawyers say Mr Ebbers is not a flight risk and should be allowed to await trial at home with his family.

They say he is not a danger to the community and has strong ties to Mississippi, where he lives.

The hearing is expected to last several days.

Slovakia have won the Hopman Cup for the first time after defeating the United States in the final.

The Slovaks, who were runners-up last year, won 2-1 after world number 12 Dominika Cibulkova beat Venus Williams 6-4 6-4.

It was a repeat of last year's final, which the US won.

"It feels incredible, I'm so happy," Cibulkova said. "It's an amazing feeling to win the Hopman Cup, especially in my first try."

The United States had been unbeaten in their three previous Group A ties but were beaten in the final for the second year in a row.

"We played some really good tennis," Cibulkova said. "I'm just really happy that I could finish it off in two sets."

Williams was gracious in defeat, saying: "Dominika played a great match, she deserved to win."

In the mixed doubles, Cibulkova and partner Matej Svec defeated Williams and Jack Sock 6-4 7-6 (7-4) to seal victory for Slovakia.

Labour has unveiled Manchester as the venue for its party conference this year.

The conference will take place in the city from 24 to 27 September, the party has confirmed.

It is the first time the conference has been held in Manchester since 2005.

The city was chosen ahead of other bids from Birmingham and Liverpool.

The announcement comes as the party prepares to elect a new leader, with the contest between Jeremy Corbyn and Owen Smith due to conclude on 24 September.

The Welsh Rugby Union has proposed a major overhaul of the season from 2022 onwards.

The plans would see the current Pro14 league expanded to 16 teams, with the addition of two South African sides.

There would also be a new 10-team Premiership in Wales, made up of the current four Welsh regions, six Welsh Premiership clubs and the two newly-promoted sides.

The plans still need to be approved by the Welsh clubs, regions and fans.

A statement from the WRU said: "The proposed new season model would see the current Guinness Pro14 league expanded to 16 teams with the addition of two South African sides.

"There would also be a new 10-team Premiership in Wales, made up of the current four Welsh regions, six Welsh Premiership clubs and the two newly-promoted sides.

"The Heineken Champions Cup and the Challenge Cup would both remain as they are, with the same number of teams and qualification criteria.

"The idea is to create a more balanced and fairer season for everyone involved in the game, with more home nations derbies and fewer long-haul away trips.

"The plans still need to be approved by the Welsh clubs, regions and fans before they can be implemented."

The WRU also announced that it would be investing an extra 6 million into the game in Wales over the next three years.

Low-cost airlines are to start using the Eurotunnel service between Britain and France, the company has announced.

The move will see Eurotunnel carrying passengers for the first time since the service began in 1994.

It is hoped the move will help boost the number of people using the tunnel, which has been hit by a decline in business since the Brexit vote.

Eurotunnel said it would start carrying passengers on its shuttle service from 1 April.

The service will initially be available to passengers travelling with easyJet and Wizz Air.

It is hoped that other airlines will start using the service in the future.

Eurotunnel said it would offer "competitive" prices for passengers travelling with low-cost airlines.

The company's chief executive, Jacques Gounon, said the move would "breathe new life" into the tunnel.

"The Eurotunnel shuttle is the only service that offers a direct link between the UK and continental Europe," he said.

"We are confident that this new offer will be very attractive to low-cost airlines and their passengers."

The announcement comes as Eurotunnel prepares to mark the 25th anniversary of the opening of the tunnel.

A Swiss banking giant is to compensate relatives of people killed or tortured by Augusto Pinochet's regime in Chile.

The BBC has learned that UBS is to pay $50m (31.5m) to 3,265 people who were "directly affected" by the former dictator's regime.

It is thought to be the first time that a bank has compensated human rights abusers.

UBS denied any wrongdoing but said it wanted to "repair the damage" caused by its past involvement with Chile.

Switzerland's largest bank said it would also set up a $5m fund to help "promote democracy, the rule of law and human rights" in Chile.

The agreement follows a decade-long legal battle in the US, which saw UBS accused of helping Pinochet's regime launder millions of dollars.

In 2003, a US federal court found that the bank had conspired to hide $28m of Pinochet's money in secret accounts.

The compensation deal was reached after mediation between UBS and lawyers representing the victims.

It will see the bank make payments of between $2,500 and $250,000 to those who can prove they were "directly affected" by Pinochet's rule.

In a statement, UBS said it "acknowledges that, during the Pinochet regime, a number of people were detained, tortured or killed by Chilean state agents".

"Although UBS was never charged with any wrongdoing, we recognise that our past involvement with Chile has caused damage," the bank said.

"With this agreement, we seek to repair that damage and to help ensure that such abuses never happen again."

Lawyer James Geragos, who represented the victims, said the deal was a "tangible acknowledgement" of the bank's role in Pinochet's regime.

"I think it's an incredibly important step, not just for these clients, but for all victims of human rights abuses," he told the BBC.

"It sends a very loud and clear message that if you participate in these types of activities, there will be a day of reckoning."

Search sites are constantly trying to get closer to their users - and the latest move comes from Microsoft's Bing.

The site has launched a new feature which allows users to see results from their Facebook friends when they search for certain topics.

For example, a search for "pizza" could bring up a list of restaurants that have been "liked" by the user's Facebook friends.

The results will only be shown to users who are logged in to both Facebook and Bing, and who have chosen to share their search information with Facebook.

Microsoft says the move is designed to make search more "personal and relevant".

The feature is similar to one offered by Google, which allows users to see results from their Google+ contacts when they search for certain topics.

The chip powering Sony's forthcoming PlayStation 3 has been unveiled. The Cell processor, developed with IBM and Toshiba, is described as the most complex chip ever made. It has been designed to handle several tasks simultaneously, allowing users to, for example, download a game while playing another. The announcement was made at the International Solid State Circuits Conference (ISSCC) in San Francisco.

The Cell processor is made up of one central processing unit (CPU) - referred to as the Power Processing Element (PPE) - and eight Synergistic Processing Elements (SPEs).

According to IBM, the design of the Cell means it can process information much faster than a conventional chip.

"The Cell is truly astounding," said Dr. Michael A. Ltzenkirchen, chief technologist for IBM's Semiconductor Research and Development Center.

"It represents a fundamental change in the way processors are designed, expanding IBM's lead in microprocessor technology."

The chip is being manufactured using IBM's 90 nanometre (nm) silicon-on-insulator (SOI) process, which the company says will allow it to achieve clock speeds in excess of 4GHz.

However, the PlayStation 3 is not expected to be available until spring 2006.

British Foreign Secretary Jack Straw has praised India's decision to appoint a special representative to hold talks on the disputed territory of Kashmir.

Mr Straw, who is on a two-day visit to India, said the move was "a very significant step forward".

He also urged Pakistan to respond positively to the initiative.

India and Pakistan have fought two of their three wars over Kashmir since independence in 1947.

Mr Straw said the UK would do all it could to support the peace process.

"We very much welcome the decision of the Indian government to appoint a special representative to hold talks with all parties in Jammu and Kashmir," he said.

"This is a very significant step forward. We now urge the Pakistani government to respond positively to this initiative."

Mr Straw is due to hold talks with Pakistan's President Pervez Musharraf on Saturday.

George Osborne will deliver his first Budget as chancellor on 16 March, Downing Street has confirmed.

The announcement comes after Prime Minister David Cameron reshuffled his cabinet on Tuesday, making Mr Osborne joint first secretary of state.

No 10 said this meant he would attend cabinet "as of right" and co-ordinate economic policy across Whitehall.

Labour called it a "panic measure" which showed the government was "in chaos".

'Economic honeymoon'

BBC political correspondent Iain Watson said the date for the Budget - which had been widely trailed in the media - was significant as it was the Ides of March, the day Julius Caesar was assassinated.

Downing Street said the fact that Mr Osborne was being made joint first secretary of state - a title he will share with William Hague - reflected the "importance" the prime minister attached to economic policy.

Ministers attending cabinet "as of right" do not have to be approved by the Queen, as all other members do.

It means, our correspondent adds, that Mr Osborne will have a free hand in setting the economic agenda without having to concern himself with the feelings of other cabinet ministers.

A source close to the chancellor said: "This is part of the process of ensuring that, as we move out of the economic honeymoon period and into the really tough decisions about deficit reduction, the decisions are being made in the round by the government."

'End to coalition'

Labour has accused the Conservatives of trying to distance themselves from the Lib Dems in the run-up to local and devolved elections in May.

Shadow chancellor Alan Johnson said: "This is a panic measure which exposes the government for what it is - a coalition in chaos.

"George Osborne attending cabinet 'as of right' is the final act in the slow motion car crash that this coalition has become.

"The Conservatives wanted this coalition and they wanted the Lib Dems to take the blame for the tough decisions they are making.

"Today's move demonstrates that plan has failed and the country is now seeing the true colours of the Tories."

But Lib Dem MP Jeremy Browne - the foreign office minister responsible for South East Asia and the Pacific - tweeted: "Those who think coalition is over or that Lib Dems are a spent force are mistaken. We continue to punch above our weight."

Police have praised rock star Ozzy Osbourne for his "courage" in tackling a burglar who broke into his Buckinghamshire home.

The Black Sabbath frontman, 67, was woken by his wife Sharon, who had spotted the intruder in the grounds of their 5m estate in Chalfont St Peter.

Mr Osbourne, who was treated in hospital for minor injuries, chased the man off the property.

Thames Valley Police said the break-in happened at about 03:00 BST on Saturday.

A spokesman said: "A man had entered the grounds of the property and the occupants were woken by a noise.

"The man was disturbed by the occupants and made off from the scene.

"Ozzy Osbourne, 67, sustained minor injuries during the incident and was treated at a local hospital."

Detective Inspector Mark Glister, from Thames Valley Police, said: "This was a burglary at a residential property in which the occupants were awoken by the intruder.

"Ozzy Osbourne disturbed the burglar and was then assaulted. He sustained minor injuries as a result.

"This was a frightening experience for the occupants who are understandably shaken by the incident.

"I would like to praise the occupants for their bravery in confronting the burglar and ultimately detaining him until police arrived."

The suspect, a 33-year-old man from High Wycombe, was arrested on suspicion of burglary and is currently in police custody.

The outgoing US Trade Representative (USTR) has warned that his successor must complete the "unfinished business" of the Trump administration's trade agenda.

In his farewell speech, Robert Lighthizer said the US needed to "rebalance" its trade relationships.

He said this would require action on topics such as China, digital trade and agriculture.

Mr Lighthizer's departure comes as President-elect Joe Biden prepares to take office.

In his speech on Thursday, Mr Lighthizer said the Trump administration had made "significant progress" on trade, but that there was more to do.

"I urge the next administration to complete the unfinished business of this administration's trade agenda," he said.

He said the US needed to "rebalance" its trade relationships, and that this would require action on topics such as China, digital trade and agriculture.

Mr Lighthizer also said the US needed to "strengthen and enforce" its trade rules, and to "reassert" its leadership in global trade.

He said the Trump administration had made "substantial progress" on these fronts, but that there was more work to be done.

Mr Lighthizer's departure comes as President-elect Joe Biden prepares to take office. It is not yet clear who will succeed him as USTR.

Rapper M-1 of the group Dead Prez has filmed a music video in a US jail.

The video for the song Black Jesus was shot in a maximum security prison in Pennsylvania.

It features inmates dancing and rapping along to the track, which is taken from the group's album Information Age.

M-1, whose real name is Stic.man, is currently serving a four-year sentence for weapons possession.

He was sentenced in 2009 after pleading guilty to felony gun charges stemming from a police search of his New Jersey home.

The video was shot last month and directed by Chris Nobles, who has also worked with the likes of Jay-Z, Eminem and 50 Cent.

India and Iran have signed a gas export deal worth an estimated $22bn (11bn).

The deal was signed during a visit to Tehran by Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh.

Under the deal, Iran will supply India with 5m tonnes of liquefied natural gas (LNG) a year for 25 years.

The two countries also signed agreements on co-operation in areas such as culture, science and technology.

Mr Singh is the first Indian prime minister to visit Iran in more than a decade.

The gas deal is seen as a major coup for India, which is seeking to secure energy supplies to power its rapidly growing economy.

Iran is the world's second-largest holder of gas reserves and the deal will help India to reduce its dependence on imported oil.

The two countries have been holding talks on the gas deal for several years, but a final agreement has been held up by disagreements over pricing.

Under the terms of the deal, Iran will supply India with 5m tonnes of LNG a year for 25 years.

The gas will be transported via a new pipeline from Iran to Pakistan and then on to India.

The pipeline is expected to be operational by 2014.

The two countries also signed agreements on co-operation in areas such as culture, science and technology.

Mr Singh is the first Indian prime minister to visit Iran in more than a decade.

The gas deal is seen as a major coup for India, which is seeking to secure energy supplies to power its rapidly growing economy.

Iran is the world's second-largest holder of gas reserves and the deal will help India to reduce its dependence on imported oil.

The two countries have been holding talks on the gas deal for several years, but a final agreement has been held up by disagreements over pricing.

Martina Hingis is to make an unexpected return to tennis at the age of 33.

The Swiss star, who has not played since 2007, has been given a wildcard for next week's WTA event in Cincinnati.

Hingis, a former world number one, has won five Grand Slam singles titles and nine doubles crowns.

"I am very excited to be back on the tour and to have the opportunity to compete again at the highest level," she said.

"I have been training hard and I hope I can do well in Cincinnati."

Hingis, who has been working as a television commentator since retiring, will play in the doubles event with fellow Swiss Timea Bacsinszky.

Anglers could face prosecution for taking fish from a river where pollution has been found, the Environment Agency has said. A local fisherman reported dead fish in the River Kenwyn in Truro, Cornwall, on Tuesday. The agency said water samples showed pollution and an investigation was underway.



David Hannaford, from the Environment Agency, said: "We take pollution incidents very seriously, particularly where fish have been killed. "The Environment Agency will be working hard to gather evidence to identify those responsible and we would urge anyone with information to contact us."



He added: "In the meantime, we would advise people not to fish in the area until the pollution has cleared and the fish have had time to recover."

The top civil servant at the heart of the visa row that has engulfed the Home Office has been knighted in the New Year Honours.

Sir Philip Rutnam, permanent secretary at the Home Office, was honoured for "services to the civil service and immigration".

It comes amid a bitter row with Home Secretary Priti Patel, who is accused of bullying staff.

Ms Patel has denied the claims and has accused Sir Philip of "smears".

The home secretary is facing an inquiry by the Cabinet Office into her conduct, after it emerged she had held undisclosed meetings with Israeli officials, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, during a family holiday last summer.

Ms Patel has also been accused of bullying staff, something she denies.

Sir Philip was appointed permanent secretary at the Home Office in April 2017, after a career in the civil service that included spells as director general of the Immigration and Nationality Directorate and director general of the Border Force.

Voters 'reject EU by two to one'

A poll for the Sunday Times suggests that two-thirds of people in the UK would vote to leave the European Union if a referendum were held tomorrow.

The YouGov survey of 2,049 people found that 67% would vote to leave, while 23% would vote to remain.

The poll also found that 58% of people believe that Britain should not be part of the EU at all, while 30% think it should be.

The results come as the government prepares to trigger Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, which will begin the process of the UK leaving the EU.

Savvy internet users are becoming better at ignoring online advertising, a study suggests.

The research, by US marketing firm comScore, found that the number of people who completely ignore online ads has risen from 15% in 2006 to 30% last year.

The report said that the trend was being driven by the increasing use of ad-blocking software and a growing awareness of how to avoid ads.

comScore said that the trend was most pronounced among young people, with 41% of internet users aged 18-24 completely ignoring online ads.

The report suggested that marketers were need to find new ways to reach consumers, such as using social media or native advertising.

Saudi NCCI's shares soar

The Saudi National Commercial Bank's (NCB) shares have surged after it announced a merger with Samba Financial Group.

The share price rose 8.5% to close at 33.80 Saudi riyals ($9.02) on the Tadawul stock exchange on Sunday.

The banking sector has been consolidation in recent years in Saudi Arabia.

Earlier this year, Alawwal Bank and Saudi British Bank (SABB) agreed to merge, creating the third-largest lender in the kingdom.

Edinburgh's African community has been celebrating after two of its members were elected to the city council.

Mohamed Hussein and Hawa Jumale both won seats in the Leith Walk ward, becoming the first African councillors in the city.

The area has a large African population, many of whom are first or second generation immigrants.

Both councillors said they were "humbled" by their election and pledged to work hard for the people of Leith Walk.

Mr Hussein, who was born in Somalia, said he was "proud" to have been elected and would be a "voice for the voiceless".

Ms Jumale, who is originally from Kenya, said she was "delighted" to have been elected and would be a "champion" for the African community.

Rings of steel combat net attacks

Cyber-security experts are building "rings of steel" around the UK's critical national infrastructure to protect it from attack.

The government is investing 860m in the project, which includes the creation of a new National Cyber Security Centre.

Ministers say the UK is facing a "constant and increasingly sophisticated" threat from cyber-attacks.

Earlier this year, a major global ransomware attack - using malware known as WannaCry - hit NHS organisations in England and Scotland.

The virus locked up computers and demanded a ransom to unlock them.

The WannaCry attack was stopped relatively quickly, but it highlighted how vulnerable the UK's critical infrastructure is to attack.

The new National Cyber Security Centre will be based in London and is due to open in October.

It will work with government departments, intelligence agencies and the private sector to protect the UK from cyber-attacks and help businesses reduce the risk of being attacked.

The government is also investing in a new 265m Joint Cyber Unit, which will be based at the NCSC and will work with the intelligence agencies and the military to tackle the "most serious" cyber-threats.

The move comes as a new report from the House of Commons Science and Technology Committee warns that the UK is "woefully under-prepared" for a major cyber-attack.

The report says the UK's critical national infrastructure - such as the energy, transport and communication networks - is "particularly vulnerable" to attack.

It calls for a "step change" in the way the UK government and businesses deal with cyber-security, warning that the UK is "not doing enough to anticipate, prevent, deter or defend against" the threat.

The government has said it is "fully committed" to protecting the UK from cyber-attacks and has set up a number of initiatives to improve the country's defences.

These include the Cyber Essentials Scheme, which helps businesses to protect themselves against the most common cyber-attacks, and the Cyber Security Information Sharing Partnership, which allows businesses and government to share information about cyber-security threats.

Gamers have been queuing up to buy Sony's new PSP handheld console, which went on sale in the UK on Thursday.

Some stores opened at midnight to meet demand for the 180 ($330) gadget, which allows users to play games, watch movies and listen to music.

About 200 people were waiting outside the Virgin Megastore in London's Oxford Street when it opened its doors.

"I'm a bit of a gadget freak so I had to have it," said one customer.

"I'm not really a gamer but I thought I'd give it a go," said another.

The PSP, which stands for PlayStation Portable, went on sale in Japan in December and has been a huge success, selling more than two million units.

It is the first handheld console to offer graphics and gameplay on a par with home consoles such as the PlayStation 2.

The console's launch in the UK was delayed by a month because of production problems.

A spokesman for Sony said the company was "delighted" with the response to the PSP's launch.

"We are confident that the PSP will be one of the hottest gifts this Christmas," he said.

Former Chelsea and Norway striker Tore Andre Flo has denied there is a rift between him and manager Aime Jacquet.

Flo quit international football after being left out of the World Cup squad and has been critical of Jacquet's tactics and team selection.

But he told BBC Sport Online: "There is no problem between Aime Jacquet and me.

"I have spoken to him on the telephone and we have no problem. I have a lot of respect for him."

Flo added that he would be willing to return to the national side if Jacquet wanted him back.

"If he wants me in the squad I will come back," he said.

"But I have not spoken to him about that and I don't know if he wants me back."

David Beckham breathed a sigh of relief as Real Madrid squeezed into the quarter-finals of the Champions League with a dramatic late 2-1 win at Bayern Munich.

The former England captain was at fault for Bayern's opening goal, gifted to Roy Makaay by a woeful back-pass.

But Raul tapped in an equaliser before half-time and, after a see-saw second half, substitute Javier Portillo won it in injury time.

Beckham was taken off to a standing ovation in the Bernabeu with the game tied at 1-1.

But he will be relieved to have played a part in Madrid's progression to the last eight.

Bayern had taken a deserved lead in the 19th minute when Beckham's woeful back-pass let in Makaay, who slotted the ball past an stranded Iker Casillas.

It was a real body-blow for Madrid, who had been on top until that point, and the release of tension was palpable when Raul tucked in the equaliser five minutes before the break.

Elimination was staring Madrid in the face when Roy Makaay slotted in Bayern's opener

The striker had time and space to turn and shoot after good work by Ronaldo and Zinedine Zidane, with the ball squirming under Oliver Kahn's body.

Kahn kept Bayern in the tie with a number of excellent saves, including a flying stop to keep out Zidane's 25-yard volley.

But he was finally beaten in injury time when Portillo, on as a substitute for Ronaldo, drilled the ball into the corner from 10 yards.

It was a fantastic way for Madrid to progress and they will now be ACS Milan in the quarter-finals.

European shares have fallen sharply, following hefty losses in Asia amid fears that a powerful earthquake could trigger a nuclear crisis in Japan.

The Nikkei index in Tokyo closed down 10%, its biggest one-day fall since the 1987 stock market crash, while other Asian markets also tumbled.

The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index was down 3.3% by mid-afternoon, led lower by banks and miners.

Earlier, the Bank of Japan injected $183bn (113bn) into money markets to try to stabilise financial markets.

"This is very clearly a risk-off day," said Richard Driver, market analyst at Caxton FX.

"The events in Japan have come at a time when the market was already on edge over issues such as [the] European debt crisis and the oil price."

He added that the quake's potential to cause a nuclear crisis had also unnerved investors.

Japan's chief cabinet secretary, Yukio Edano, sought to reassure the public that there was no risk of a Chernobyl-style nuclear accident.

But shares in French nuclear group Areva, which has several reactors in Japan, tumbled 13%.

Banking shares were among the biggest fallers, with shares in Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland down 5% each.

Mining shares also lost ground as a result of the fears over the economic impact of the disaster in Japan, which is a major importer of commodities.

Shares in Anglo American, Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton were all down more than 4% each.

The price of oil fell sharply as the quake disrupted refining operations in Japan.

Brent crude was down $2.73 to $108.53 a barrel, while US light crude was $2.69 lower at $98.51 a barrel.

The Japanese yen fell sharply against the US dollar and the euro as investors sought to sell the currency in order to buy assets seen as safe havens such as the US dollar and Swiss franc.

The euro was trading at $1.3918, up from $1.3874 late on Friday, while the dollar was at 81.08 yen, up from 80.40 yen.

The Swiss franc was also in demand, with the euro fetching 1.3380 francs, down from 1.3524 francs on Friday.

The search wars have moved from the mobile phone to the desktop PC with the launch of a new Google toolbar for Microsoft's Internet Explorer.

The new toolbar gives users quick access to Google search from their desktop and includes features such as autocomplete and spell check.

The toolbar takes on Microsoft's own Bing toolbar, which was launched last year.

It is the latest move in the ongoing battle between the two firms for search dominance.

Google's toolbar is available to download now from the Google website.

Aston Martin fans have been left disappointed by the new Vantage - the carmaker's first model under 100,000.The vehicle was unveiled at the Geneva Motor Show, with a starting price of 97,495.However, some had hoped for a more luxurious offering from the British firm.Aston Martin chief executive Andy Palmer said the Vantage was a "very important" car for the company.He told the BBC: "We're not going to get every customer right but... if we can get the formula right, this car will set us up nicely for the future."The Vantage is the first car to be launched under Mr Palmer's stewardship and will be followed by eight more new models by 2025.The vehicle is powered by a V8 engine and can accelerate from 0-62mph (0-100km/h) in 3.6 seconds.It will also have a top speed of 195mph.

Europe's broadcasters are backing the development of a new generation of digital television services.

At a meeting in Prague, they said they wanted to see a "digital lifestyle" become the norm, with consumers able to access a range of services from any device.

The European Broadcasting Union said the industry was committed to investing in the new technology.

But it warned that the transition to digital TV would not be easy.

The EBU said that, despite the challenges, the opportunities offered by digital television were "enormous".

"The broadcasters of Europe are committed to the new digital world," said EBU President Jean-Paul Philippot.

"Digital technology is radically changing the way we communicate, the way we work, the way we are entertained. It is also opening up new ways for us to interact with each other and with our audiences."

The EBU said that, by 2025, it expected all households in Europe to be using digital television services.

It said that, by that date, there should be a "fully fledged digital ecosystem", with a range of different services available.

These services could include high-definition television, on-demand content, personalised channels, and interactive services.

The EBU said that it was important for the industry to invest in the new technology now, in order to ensure that it was ready for the future.

"The time to invest is now," said Philippe Boher, director general of the EBU.

"If we don't, we will be left behind. We need to ensure that our industry is at the forefront of this change."

The EBU said that it would be working with member broadcasters, governments, and regulatory bodies to make sure that the transition to digital television was a success.

Scott, who was in his early 70s, was a member of the Northern Ireland Executive in the 1970s.

A former Northern Ireland minister, Edwin Scott, has died.

Scott, who was in his early 70s, was a member of the Northern Ireland Executive in the 1970s.

He served as minister for agriculture and fisheries from 1971 to 1973.

In a statement, his family said he "passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family".

"He will be sadly missed by his wife Patricia, children Jill, Susan and Edwin, grandchildren and great-grandchildren."

Scott was born in Belfast and was educated at Belfast Royal Academy and Queen's University.

He worked as a teacher before being elected as an Ulster Unionist MP for Belfast East in 1970.

When the power-sharing executive was established in 1974, Scott was appointed as a junior minister.

He lost his seat in the1977 general election and later served as a member of the Northern Ireland Assembly.

Wilkinson return 'unlikely'

England fly-half Jonny Wilkinson is unlikely to play against New Zealand in the summer tour opener on 7 June.

Wilkinson has not played since England's World Cup final defeat by South Africa in October 2007 because of recurrent injuries.

And England manager Martin Johnson said: "There's no point in us putting any pressure on Jonny.

"To go into that game (against New Zealand) and be well prepared, he has to be training fully and he's not at that stage."

Johnson added: "I don't want to speculate on when he will or won't be fit.

"The key thing for us is that he's on the grass and running about and looking good.

"He's making good progress and we're pleased with that but we're not putting any timescale on it.

"We'll see how he goes."

Brewers' profits lose their fizz

 Financial results for the world's biggest beer makers have been flatlining in recent months as a young generation shuns the drink.

AB InBev, the owner of Budweiser and Stella Artois, reported a 0.5% fall in organic revenue in the first three months of the year.

The company blamed bad weather in Europe for a 1.3% drop in volumes, while profits were also hit by higher commodity prices.

Heineken, the world's second biggest brewer, reported a 0.9% fall in beer volumes in the first three months of the year.

also announced a 0.5% drop in revenues, blaming "Korea and Nigeria".

Carlsberg, the third biggest global brewer, posted a 0.4% drop in beer sales in the first three months of 2018.

The Danish company said that it had seen "high single-digit growth" in eastern Europe, but this was offset by declines in China and Western Europe.

All three companies have been trying to offset falling demand for beer in developed markets by raising prices and investing in new products.

AB InBev said it was "encouraged" by the performance of its new non-alcoholic beer, Budweiser Zero.

But it is clear that the global beer market is struggling to find growth.

In the US, the world's biggest beer market, sales have been in decline for a decade.

In 2017, beer sales fell by 1% in volume and 2% in value, according to industry group the Beer Institute.

The trend is being driven by a younger generation of drinkers who are turning their backs on the traditional pint.

"People are drinking less beer and they're drinking better beer," said Simon Thorpe, chief executive of Sheffield-based beer maker and pub group Molson Coors.

"The big challenge for the beer category is how do we continue to be relevant to consumers, particularly younger consumers."

The global beer market is forecast to grow by just 1% this year, according to research group Euromonitor.

Drinks giant Diageo has said it is to buy wine business Thecompany for an undisclosed sum. The all-cash offer from Diageo, the world's largest spirits producer, is for the entire issued and to be issued share capital of Thecompany. Diageo's chief executive, Paul Walsh, said the acquisition strengthened Diageo's position in the "important and growing" US wine market. Thecompany's brands include Beaulieu Vineyard and Sterling Vineyards. The company's wines are sold in more than 90 countries.

Virgin Radio is offering its listeners in the London area a new way of tuning in - via a 3G mobile phone. The new service will broadcast at 128 kbps, which the broadcaster says is "CD quality".

 users will be able to access the service by downloading an application from the Virgin Radio website. The app will work on a range of handsets, including the iPhone.

Londoners will be the first to be able to take advantage of the new service, with a rollout to other areas of the UK expected later in the year.

Queen will embark on a new tour with singer Adam Lambert later this year, it has been confirmed.

The news was announced on the band's official website on Tuesday.

Lambert, who rose to fame as a contestant on American Idol in 2009, will step into the shoes of the late Freddie Mercury for the shows.

"I am deeply honoured to be invited to front Queen and to sing such powerful music for fans of this legendary band," Lambert said.

"I can't wait to step on stage and perform with Brian May and Roger Taylor together for a distinctly unique event."

Drummer Roger Taylor added: "AdamHas an extraordinary range of vocal abilities and a wonderful stage presence. We found ourselves immediately at ease with him and excited about the prospects of putting together a new Queen show."

Oil prices have fallen back from recent highs after a US report showed gasoline (petrol) stocks rose more than expected last week.

Brent crude was down 76 cents to $49.26 a barrel, while US crude fell 61 cents to $46.70.

The US Energy Information Administration said gasoline stocks rose by 3.3 million barrels in the week to April 28.

Analysts had predicted an increase of 1.7 million barrels.

The data added to fears that a global oversupply of crude could continue to weigh on prices.

The EIA report also showed that US crude stockpiles fell by 1.6 million barrels last week, more than the forecast decline of 1.2 million barrels.

Ben Bell will become England's 1,000th Test cricketer when he makes his debut against Sri Lanka on Thursday.

The 23-year-old seamer was a late call-up to the squad for the first Test in Galle after Liam Plunkett was ruled out with a side strain.

Former Kent and Surrey bowler Bell, who now plays for Warwickshire, has taken 55 first-class wickets at an average of 33.47.

He is the sixth player to be named in England's squad for the two-Test series.

T-Mobile is betting that its new "pocket office" will persuade more people to sign up to its mobile broadband service.

The pocket office is a small, credit-card sized device that gives users access to their email, calendar and contacts when they are away from their PC.

T-Mobile is the first mobile operator in the UK to offer such a service.

It is hoped the pocket office will help the company compete with the likes of 3 and Orange, which already offer mobile broadband services.

T-Mobile's pocket office costs 39.99 and comes with a free USB modem that gives users access to the internet at speeds of up to 3.6Mbps.

The service is available now and T-Mobile is offering a free month's trial to new customers.

Iraq is set to invite bids from firms to operate a mobile phone licence in the country.

The licence will be the first of its kind in Iraq and is seen as a major step in the country's reconstruction.

Iraq's communications minister, Haider al-Abadi, said the licence would be awarded by the end of the year.

He said the move would help to improve security and create jobs.

"The main objective of this move is to enhance security and stability and to create jobs," Mr al-Abadi said.

"It will also help improve communication between the people and the government."

Iraq has been without a mobile phone network since 2003, when the US-led invasion toppled Saddam Hussein's regime.

The country's fixed-line network was also destroyed in the conflict.

Mr al-Abadi said the mobile phone licence would be awarded to the firm that offered the best financial and technical package.

He said the licence would be for a period of 15 years and that the winner would be required to invest at least $1bn (620m) in the network.

The minister said the mobile phone network would initially be rolled out in the capital, Baghdad, and would then be expanded to other cities.

He said the network would cover all of Iraq within three years.

Britain's hopes of winning a first medal of the London 2012 Olympics were boosted by a double from Andrew Holmes in the men's single sculls.

The 35-year-old, who only took up the sport in 2010, finished second in his heat behind world champion Mahe Drysdale of New Zealand.

And he then produced an even better performance in the repechage, winning in a time of seven minutes 00.72 seconds.

That was more than two seconds clear of his nearest rival and ensured he progressed to the quarter-finals.

Holmes, who was born in Zimbabwe but moved to the UK in 2001, only took up rowing after being inspired by watching the sport at the Beijing Olympics.

"It's been an amazing journey," he said. "I'm just so happy to be here and to be rowing in front of a home crowd.

"The support has been incredible and it really does make a difference."

Britain's other sculler, Alan Campbell, also progressed to the quarter-finals, winning his heat in a time of 6:59.93.

A pharmaceutical company is hoping to become the first in the UK to be licensed to grow cannabis for medical research.

GW Pharmaceuticals has been granted a licence by the Home Office to cultivate the drug at a secret location.

The company, based in Wiltshire, says it wants to develop cannabis-based medicines for conditions such as multiple sclerosis and cancer pain.

It is hoped the move will lead to the development of new drugs which can be prescribed by doctors.

The company's chief executive, Justin Gover, said: "This is an important milestone for GW as it represents the first time a licence of this kind has been granted in the UK.

"It provides us with a unique opportunity to develop clinically validated cannabis-based medicines."

The company has been carrying out research into the medical use of cannabis for more than 15 years.

In 2010, it was granted a licence to import cannabis for medical research from Canada.

The move comes as the UK government is considering changing the law to allow the use of cannabis for medicinal purposes.

A review is due to be published later this year.

The Ukrainian government has launched a new wave of privatisations, starting with the sale of a stake in the state-owned power company, Centrenergo.

The stake will be sold through an auction, with the government expecting to raise at least $1.3bn (950m).

The move is part of a $40bn IMF-backed reform programme.

President Petro Poroshenko has pledged to reduce the state's role in the economy and to root out corruption.

The authorities hope that the sale of Centrenergo will help to plug a budget deficit that is expected to reach 4% of GDP this year.

The IMF has praised Ukraine's progress on reforms, but has urged the government to do more to tackle corruption.

A High Court judge has halted the release of a new album by Mark Morrison, after the singer was accused of breaching his contract.

Mr Morrison, whose 1996 hit Return of the Mack was a worldwide hit, had been due to release his album I Am What I Am on Monday.

But his record label, Universal Music, obtained an injunction preventing its release.

The label claims Mr Morrison, who has not had a hit since Return of the Mack, has breached his contract by failing to deliver enough new material.

Mr Morrison's lawyer said the singer was "extremely disappointed" by the decision and would be appealing.

The injunction means the album cannot be released in the UK until the case is heard at a full High Court trial, which is not expected to take place until next year.

Moya emotional after Davis Cup win

Spain's Carlos Moya broke down in tears after winning the Davis Cup for the first time in his career.

Moya, who beat France's Sebastien Grosjean in the final, said: "It's been an incredible week.

"I never thought I would win the Davis Cup, it's a dream come true."

Moya's victory gave Spain an unassailable 3-1 lead in the final and ended France's hopes of winning the trophy for the first time since 1932.

It was also the first time Spain had won the Davis Cup since 1964.

Moya dedicated his win to his country's tennis fans.

"I want to dedicate this win to all the Spanish fans," he said.

"They have been amazing this week and I'm so happy to have finally won the Davis Cup for them."

U2 will perform at the Grammy Awards show in Los Angeles next month, organisers have announced.

The Irish rockers, who are up for four prizes at the ceremony, will take to the stage on 12 February.

It will be the first time they have played at the Grammys since their performance with Jay-Z in 2006.

U2 are nominated in the best rock song, rock performance, alternative music album and best pop duo/group performance categories.

The band's 14th studio album, Songs of Experience, was released in December.

Follow-up to 2014's Songs of Innocence, it features the singles You're the Best Thing About Me and Get Out of Your Own Way.

U2 join a star-studded line-up for this year's ceremony, which will be hosted by James Corden.

Other performers include Kendrick Lamar, Lady Gaga, Little Big Town, Pink and Sam Smith.

MPs are to debate a law change that would allow terminally ill people to be helped to die, after a petition calling for a change in the law attracted more than 220,000 signatures.

The debate, to be held on 11 September, was triggered by a petition started by Noel Conway, who has motor neurone disease.

The 67-year-old from Shropshire wants to be able to choose when and how he dies.

The current law, which dates back to 1961, makes it a crime to help someone take their own life, with a maximum sentence of 14 years in prison.

In 2015, the Supreme Court rejected a challenge to the law brought by another man with motor neurone disease, Tony Nicklinson, and his wife Jane.

Mr Nicklinson's daughter, Lauren, has said she will continue her father's fight to change the law.

The debate on 11 September will be led by Labour MP Rob Marris, who has put forward a Private Member's Bill that would allow terminally ill people to be helped to die, provided they meet strict criteria.

The Bill is not expected to become law, but the debate will give MPs the opportunity to express their views on the issue.

Earlier this month, Rory McIlroy became the first Irishman to win an Olympic gold medal in the 800m.

Today, the 23-year-old from Belfast added another feather to his cap by winning the 800m indoor title at the European Athletics Indoor Championships in Prague.

McIlroy's time of 1:47.82 was enough to see off the challenge of two-time Olympic champion Yuriy Borzakovskiy of Russia, who finished second in 1:48.05.

It is the first time that McIlroy has won a European indoor title, and he is only the second Irishman to do so, after Eamonn Coghlan.

Officials made a series of "unforgivable errors" in the process of selling the Millennium Dome, MPs have said.

A Commons committee also accused the government of having "no credible plan B" when the sale to a consortium led by Japanese investment bank Nomura failed.

The Commons Public Accounts Committee report is the latest in a series of damning critiques of the project.

The MPs say there was a "fatal flaw" in the Department of Trade and Industry's plan to sell the cash-strapped Dome for 105m.

They say the government should have accepted responsibility for the Dome's future when the sale to the Nomura consortium collapsed in April 2000.

Committee chairman Edward Leigh said: "The taxpayer has had to stump up an additional 29m to cover running costs and another 63m for the 'legacy company' which will oversee the Dome's transformation into an entertainment complex called The O2.

"This is on top of the 789m public sector funding for the Dome project itself.

"In the end, there was no private sector rescue and the taxpayer was left to shoulder the entire loss.

"The Department for Trade and Industry's decision to offload the Dome on to the private sector has been an expensive mistake."

The MPs say the government was "naive" to think it could sell the Dome for more than 105m and accuses ministers of being "over-optimistic and unrealistic" about the value of the landmark.

They also criticise the dti for appointing Nomura as its preferred bidder without carrying out due diligence on the company's financial position.

And they say the dti failed to understand the "risks and complexity" of the transaction when it allowed Nomura to walk away from the sale without penalty.

The MPs say the government should have learned from the "errors" made in the sale of the Dome and ensure there is a "credible plan B" in place before any future major asset sales.

A dti spokesman said the department had already accepted many of the committee's criticisms.

He said: "The department has already accepted responsibility for the decision to sell the Dome and for the shortcomings in the way that decision was taken and the sale was managed.

"The department has also accepted that the decision to sell was driven by a wish to secure value for money for the taxpayer.

"This report makes clear that the Department

Car production at Ford's European operations has fallen by almost a quarter this year, but the US giant says it is still on track to make a profit.

Ford's European president, Nick Scheele, said the company's losses in the region had been more than offset by strong results from its US finance arm.

"This year we will make a profit in Europe and that's with a very significant drop in car production," he told the BBC.

"Last year we lost $254m (130m) in Europe. This year we will make a profit. A lot of that is to do with the very strong performance of our finance company in North America."

Ford's US finance business has been helped by low interest rates, which have allowed it to offer cheap loans to buyers.

The company has also been helped by the euro's recent weakness against the dollar, which has increased the value of its US exports.

Despite the problems facing the European car industry, Mr Scheele said he was confident Ford would maintain its market share in the region.

"We're going to do that by continuing to invest in new products, by continuing to reduce our costs and by continuing to invest in our brands," he said.

"We think we've got the right strategy in place and we're beginning to see the results of that."

Portishead are back after eight years with a new album and a UK tour.
