The band, who last released an album in 2008, will release their fifth LP, titled "Machine Gun", on April 13.

The album was recorded over the past three years in Bristol and Los Angeles, and features contributions from Adrian Utley, Geoff Barrow's collaborator on the "Quakers" project.

Portishead will also embark on a UK tour in May, with dates in London, Manchester, Glasgow and Birmingham.

Actor Scott is new Bond favourite

The actor, who has starred in films including The 39 Steps and The 39th Parallel, is now the bookies' favourite to be the next James Bond.

The news comes after Daniel Craig announced he was stepping down from the role after 12 years.

 Scott, who is married to actress Keeley Hawes, has previously said he would "jump at the chance" to play Bond.

The actor, who is best known for his role in the TV series Mad Dogs, has also starred in films including Spy Game and Sherlock Holmes.

The US government has given foreign firms more time to comply with a law that requires them to disclose their ownership.

The change means that firms will have to disclose their "ultimate beneficial owners" to the US Treasury Department by 1 October 2018, instead of the original deadline of 1 July 2017.

The move comes after concerns were raised that the original deadline was too tight.

The US Treasury said the extra time would "provide greater certainty and clarity for firms".

The beneficial ownership rule was introduced as part of the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform law.

It requires firms to disclose their beneficial owners - defined as individuals who ultimately own or control a company - to the US Treasury's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN).

The information will be held in a database that will be accessible to financial institutions and law enforcement agencies.

The US Treasury said the rule was designed to "help fight illicit finance by making it more difficult for criminals to hide behind anonymous shell companies".

However, some business groups have raised concerns about the rule, arguing that it will impose an unnecessary burden on firms.

The US Chamber of Commerce has filed a lawsuit challenging the rule, arguing that it violates the constitutional rights of firms.

The extra time for compliance will give the Chamber of Commerce more time to make its case, as the lawsuit is not expected to be resolved before 1 July 2017.

The US regulator will rule on whether a new pain drug is safe and effective enough to be approved.

The decision on Zohydro ER will be made by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on 7 March.

The drug, which is a extended-release form of hydrocodone, is already available in other countries.

But it has been opposed by some US lawmakers and addiction experts, who say it could be abused.

Hydrocodone is a powerful opioid painkiller that is already available in the US in other forms.

But Zohydro ER is different because it is designed to be taken every 12 hours, rather than every four to six hours like other hydrocodone products.

It is also designed to be taken orally, rather than by injection.

The FDA's decision on whether to approve the drug will be based on the results of clinical trials.

The agency has already said that it is "concerned" about the potential for abuse and misuse of Zohydro ER.

But it has also said that the drug could be an important new treatment option for patients with chronic pain.

The government is to review the law on contact arrangements between parents and children, following a high-profile family court case.

The review was announced in the Commons by Justice Secretary Robert Buckland.

It will look at the options for changing the law, including giving courts more powers to ensure contact takes place.

The review comes after a father went to the High Court to try to stop his ex-partner taking their daughter to live in New Zealand.

The father, who cannot be named for legal reasons, argued that the move would breach his rights to a relationship with his child.

But the judge ruled that the mother could take the girl to New Zealand, saying it was in her best interests.

Announcing the review, Mr Buckland said the government wanted to make sure the law struck "the right balance" between the rights of parents and the best interests of children.

"We need to do everything we can to make sure that, when parents separate, the arrangements that are made for their children are workable, are in the best interests of the child and are made with the child's welfare front and centre," he said.

The review will be led by Sir Andrew McFarlane, the president of the Family Division of the High Court. It is expected to report back by the end of the year.

The Firefox browser is taking on Microsoft's Internet Explorer with a new version that promises to be faster and more secure.

The open-source software, which is free to download, has been downloaded more than 150 million times since its launch in 2004.

Its developers say the new version, Firefox 3, is twice as fast as the previous one and has a more streamlined interface.

It also includes a new security feature that warns users if they are about to visit a malicious website.

"We're very excited about Firefox 3," said Mike Beltzner, director of Firefox at the Mozilla Foundation.

"It's a huge milestone not just for our project, but for the open-source community and the web as a whole."

The new version of the browser is available in more than 70 languages and works on Windows, Mac and Linux.

Mozilla says it has fixed more than 12,000 bugs in the new version and added more than 1,000 new features.

The browser is competing against Microsoft's Internet Explorer, which is bundled with the Windows operating system.

Internet Explorer still has the lion's share of the browser market, but Firefox has been steadily gaining ground.

According to web analytics firm Net Applications, Firefox had a 21.8% share of the browser market in May, compared to IE's 67.8%.

Mozilla is hoping to increase its market share with the release of Firefox 3 and has even set a Guinness World Record for the most software downloads in a 24-hour period.

British Prime Minister Theresa May has announced a series of tax cuts for businesses and households in a bid to boost the economy after Brexit.

The measures, which will be funded by a 100 million "Brexit bonus", include a cut in corporation tax from 20% to 17% and a reduction in business rates for small businesses.

Mrs May said the economy was "resilient" but that she was "not taking anything for granted".

The Opposition Labour Party said the tax cuts were "a shot in the dark" that would not help the economy.

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said Mrs May was "out of touch" with the struggles faced by many people in the UK.

The Liberal Democrats said the tax cuts were "a desperate act of economic self-harm".

Mrs May's announcement comes as the UK prepares to leave the European Union on 29 March 2019.

A group representing former members of the Royal Regiment of Wales and the Welch Regiment says it will lobby for a separate homeland in the event of Welsh independence. The Welsh Regiments' Association claims many of its members are not Welsh and would not want to live in an independent country. It has written to First Minister Rhodri Morgan outlining its views. The Welsh government has previously insisted it would not force people to become citizens of an independent Wales.



The Welsh Regiments' Association (WRA) represents about 10,000 former soldiers who served in the two regiments, which were amalgamated in 2006 to form the Royal Welsh. In a letter to Mr Morgan, WRA chairman Alun Ffred Jones said many of its members did not have Welsh citizenship and would not want to acquire it. "We are now being realistic and telling you that, in the event of Welsh independence, we would want our own homeland within the UK," he wrote. "We are not asking for independence, we are merely being realistic."



Mr Jones, who served in the Royal Welch Fusiliers for 22 years, said members of the WRA were "very upset" at the way the Welsh government had treated them since the amalgamation of the regiments. He added: "Our two regimental museums have been closed, our home in Cardiff Castle has been given to the Welsh government and our colours have been laid up in St David's Cathedral - a building we have no connection with. "All we are asking for is a bit of fairness and understanding."



A Welsh government spokesperson said: "The Welsh government's position is clear - we would not force anyone to become a citizen of an independent Wales. "We respect the right of the Welsh Regiments' Association to put forward their views, which will be given due consideration."

British Prime Minister Tony Blair has congratulated US President George W Bush on his re-election, saying he looked forward to working with him.

In a statement, Mr Blair said: "I have congratulated President Bush on his re-election and look forward to working with him in the second term."

The two leaders have been close allies, particularly over the US-led invasion of Iraq in 2003.

However, their relationship has come under strain in recent months over the war.

Mr Blair has been criticised by some for his support of the US-led invasion, while others have accused him of not doing enough to secure peace in Iraq.

Rivals of the 400 Apple Watch are being lined up by Samsung, LG and Motorola, a new report has claimed.

The South Korean, Japanese and US firms are all working on smartwatches that will be released in the second half of the year, Bloomberg said.

The devices will be more expensive than the Apple Watch but cheaper than luxury Swiss watches, the report added.

Samsung and LG declined to comment, while Motorola could not be reached.

The Bloomberg report, which cited people familiar with the matter, said the three firms were working on devices that would be compatible with a range of smartphones.

It added that the watches would be able to make calls, access the internet and run apps.

The Apple Watch, which was unveiled in September, is due to go on sale in April.

It is the most expensive smartwatch on the market, with prices starting at $349 (230).

The Bloomberg report comes a day after it was claimed that Google was working on a smartwatch that would be released later this year.

The device, which is being developed by the search giant's Motorola unit, will be powered by Google's Android Wear operating system, Bloomberg said.

It is not clear how much the device will cost.

Smartwatches have been hailed as the next big thing in consumer electronics but so far they have failed to live up to the hype.

Sales of the devices have been disappointing, with many consumers put off by their high price tags and lack of features.

Robben sidelined with broken foot

Bayern Munich winger Arjen Robben has been ruled out for up to eight weeks with a broken foot.

The Dutchman, 31, was injured in training on Tuesday and had surgery on Wednesday.

He has scored eight goals in 15 appearances for Bayern this season and is a key player for the German champions.

Bayern are top of the Bundesliga, four points clear of second-placed Wolfsburg, and are through to the last 16 of the Champions League.

British number one Tim Henman has announced his retirement from Davis Cup tennis.

The 30-year-old, who has played in the competition for 11 years, said he wanted to focus on his singles career.

"It is with a heavy heart that I have decided to retire from Davis Cup tennis," said Henman.

"I have given the matter a great deal of thought and it is now time for me to concentrate on my singles career."

Henman has played in 37 Davis Cup ties, winning 26 of his singles matches and 14 of his doubles matches.

He made his debut in the competition in 1995 against Switzerland and helped Britain reach the semi-finals that year.

Britain have not reached the last four since then but Henman believes the team can be successful without him.

"I would like to thank everyone who has supported me throughout my Davis Cup career, especially the fans," he said.

"I am confident that the team can continue to progress and enjoy success in the future."

Britain captain Jeremy Bates said he was "disappointed" to lose Henman but respected his decision.

"I have enjoyed working with Tim over the past few years and I would like to thank him for his contribution to British tennis," said Bates.

"He has been an excellent role model for the younger players coming through and I am sure he will continue to be a great asset to British tennis."

The leaders of the three main Westminster parties should debate live on television ahead of the next general election, a former Ofcom chief says. David Currie, who chaired the regulator from 2003 to 2009, said: "It is high time the Westminster parties took this important step." He said David Cameron, Ed Miliband and Nick Clegg should hold three debates during the six-week election campaign. The Conservatives have previously said the debates should take place before the official campaigning period. The broadcasters have also been strongly opposed to that idea. In a letter to The Times, Mr Currie said the time had come for the parties to thrash out a compromise. 'Cup of tea' He wrote: "The idea that the party leaders should not debate before the official campaign period is like a footballer refusing to play before the referee blows his whistle. It ignores the fact that the crucial decisions in any election are made long before polling day and that brinksmanship is a very dangerous game to play. "The unless the politicians come to a sensible compromise on this issue, it is time for the broadcasters to stop being so coy and seize the initiative by declaring that they will go ahead and organise the debate irrespective of whether all the party leaders agree to take part. It is their duty to the public." Mr Currie, now a Labour peer, said the initiative should come from the broadcasters and not the government. A Conservative Party source said the prime minister's position on the debates had not changed. 'Up to broadcasters' The source said: "As we've always said, these debates should happen in the period when people are making their voting decisions but ultimately it's up to the broadcasters to make that decision." Mr Miliband has already called for the debates to happen during the official campaign and the governing coalition has broken down over the issue.Earlier this month the BBC's political programme This Week broadcast a special edition which saw a cup of tea take the place of Nick Clegg in what was billed as the "aspirational" post-election TV debate. The Church of Scotland has also suggested that other "voices" should be allowed to take part in the debates - with ideas including a Scottish National Party representative taking part in the TV face-offs.

The next generation of home gamers could help to drive take-up of high-definition television, according to US analysts. A report by In-Stat MDR suggests that by 2010, there will be 30 million households worldwide with an HDTV and a games console. In the US, the number of HDTV homes playing console games is expected to rise from one million in 2005 to 12 million in 2010.

The growth of HDTV is being fuelled by the introduction of cheap, high-definition capable set-top boxes and the falling price of LCD and plasma TVs.

In-Stat MDR said that the games industry was in a unique position to drive consumer demand for HDTV. "The gaming community has long been an early adopter of new technologies," said analyst Brian O'Rourke. "As HDTV penetration rates increase and the price differential between HDTV and standard-definition TV narrows, we expect console gaming to become an increasingly significant application for HDTVs."

The rise in HDTV take-up is likely to be music to the ears of the games industry, which has been struggling to boost flagging sales in recent months. In the US, sales of consoles and games fell by 7% in 2006, according to research firm NPD.

The Liberal Democrats have highlighted the problem of problem debt in the UK, saying it is a "ticking time bomb".

In a report, the party said there were 8.3 million people in the UK with problem debt, and that the issue was "widespread and growing".

The report said that problem debt was often caused by low incomes, high costs, and unexpected life events.

The party called on the government to do more to help people in problem debt, including introducing a "breathing space" scheme to give people time to get their finances in order.

The report also called for an end to "unaffordable" payday loans, and for more support for people who are struggling to pay their rent.

The Liberal Democrats said that problem debt was a "ticking time bomb" that was "widespread and growing".

The party called on the government to do more to help people in problem debt, including introducing a "breathing space" scheme to give people time to get their finances in order.

The report also called for an end to "unaffordable" payday loans, and for more support for people who are struggling to pay their rent.

Andy Murray says male players are treated more favorably than women on the ATP Tour and has called for changes to the prizes and rankings.

The Scot, who is ranked second in the world, was speaking after his win over world number one Novak Djokovic in the Qatar Open final.

"There's definitely, in my opinion, a bit of sexism in tennis," Murray told reporters.

"I think there's a bit of inequality between the men's and women's game.

"I think the ATP (the governing body of men's tennis) do a lot for the men's game, and they don't do enough for the women's game."

Murray has been an outspoken critic of sexism in tennis and has previously called for prize money at all Grand Slam tournaments to be equal.

In the Qatar Open final, Murray beat Djokovic in straight sets, 6-3, 6-4.

"I'm sure if you asked him (Djokovic), he would say the same thing," Murray said of the prize money imbalance.

"It's something that needs to be addressed. It's not equal prize money at all the Grand Slams. I think it should be."

The Qatar Open was the first men's tournament of the year to offer equal prize money to men and women.

At the Australian Open, which starts on Monday, the men's and women's winners will each take home $3.1 million.

 Murray has also called for changes to the ATP rankings system, which he says is "sexist".

"The points and the money should be equal," he said.

"The rankings are sexist. They should be based on results over a 12-month period, not two years."

Murray's comments come just days after another high-profile player, Serena Williams, suggested that women are not treated as well as men in tennis.

In an interview with BBC Sport, Williams said: "I think there is a lot of sexism in tennis. I have been a victim of it.

"I don't think there is as much respect for women as there should be."

The amount of sensitive documents being shredded by the government has increased by a third since the Conservatives came to power, according to analysis of ministerial correspondence.
In 2010-11, the government shredded 304,536 documents marked "Departmental Information Assets", up from 229,536 the previous year.
Tory MP David Davis, who obtained the figures in a parliamentary question, said they showed the "apparent contempt" ministers had for accountability.
The figures, from the National Archives, cover all documents shredded by the government, including those containing personal information.
They do not include any material which is deemed to be classified.
In his question, Mr Davis asked the government to list the total number of documents shredded by each department in each of the last five years.
The response showed that in 2010-11, the Home Office disposed of the most documents - 83,496 - followed by the Ministry of Defence, which shredded 57,036 items.

Johnny Depp has carved out an unusual career, playing everything from a pirate to a chocolate factory owner.

The actor has displayed an uncanny ability to disappear into his characters, whether they be misunderstood outsiders or larger-than-life eccentrics.

It is a skill that has won him worldwide acclaim and a loyal following of fans.

Depp was born in Kentucky in 1963, the youngest of four children.

His parents divorced when he was young and he spent much of his time with his mother, who worked as a waitress.

Depp had a troubled upbringing and was expelled from school at the age of 15.

He turned to acting as a way to escape his turbulent home life and took up various odd jobs to support himself.

Depp's big break came in the 1980s television show 21 Jump Street.

The show made him a household name and he went on to star in a string of successful films, including Edward Scissorhands, Sleepy Hollow and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

Depp has been nominated for three Academy Awards and has won a Golden Globe for his role in Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.

He has also been awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

Depp is currently starring in the fifth instalment of the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise, Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales.

The actor has said he is drawn to roles that are "a little off the beaten path".

 Depp is known for his eccentric style and off-beat sense of humour.

He has been married twice, first to Lori Anne Allison and then to model and actress Amber Heard.

The couple divorced in 2017 after 15 months of marriage.

Depp has two children, Lily-Rose and Jack, from his relationship with French actress and model Vanessa Paradis.

Defeated mayoral candidate Zac Goldsmith has said he was not personally "leant on" by the Conservative Party to resign his seat and causes a by-election.

"Of course not," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme when asked if he had been under pressure.

"I respect the view of the party," he said, adding that he would remain a Conservative MP.

 Conservative Party chairman Sir Patrick McLoughlin has said the party would "fight very hard" to keep the seat in a by-election.

Announcing his resignation on Thursday, Mr Goldsmith said he could not "ignore" the views of those who had voted to leave the EU.

But he said he would not support a Labour candidate - expected to be confirmed later as Sadiq Khan - in the by-election, expected to take place on 9 June.

In his first broadcast interview since announcing his resignation, Mr Goldsmith told the Today programme that there was a "huge disconnect" between Westminster and large parts of the country.

"The referendum has exposed that," he said.

"My problem is not with the Conservative Party, it is with the government," he said, adding that he would continue to support the Conservatives "from the back benches".

Radcliffe eyes hard line on drugs

By James Landale

Political correspondent, BBC News



The government is to increase its focus on illegal drug use as part of its wider review of crime and punishment, Home Secretary Jacqui Smith has said.

Speaking on BBC One's Sunday Politics, Ms Smith said she wanted police and prosecutors to target people who dealt in, as well as used, illegal drugs.

She said the UK's approach to drugs had "evolved" and she was looking at all options.

The government's review of sentencing will be published later this year.

The Home Office's drug strategy is already due to be refreshed next year.

'Very serious issue'

Ms Smith was appearing on Sunday Politics two days after the former home secretary David Blunkett told the BBC that the government should decriminalise cannabis.

He said that the drug was "not as harmful as classified" and that the police should concentrate their resources on harder substances.

The home secretary said that it was a "very serious issue" and she would be publishing the government's review of sentencing later this year.

"It will set out how we make sure we've got the right penalties for the most serious offences - and that drug dealing is one of those," she said.

'Significant problem'

"But we also need to make sure that we do more to stop people dealing in drugs in the first place and that's one of the things that the review of sentencing will look at."

Ms Smith said that illegal drug use was a "significant problem" in society which caused a "huge amount of crime".

"We need to do more to make sure that we target the people who are dealing in drugs as well as the people who are using them," she said.

The home secretary said that the government's approach to drugs had "evolved" over the past 11 years and she was looking at all options.

She said that the government was already spending 600m a year on drug treatment and that this was "starting to make a difference".

Howard rejects BNP's claim

The BBC has seen a leaked copy of the British National Party's (BNP) election manifesto, which calls for the "voluntary resettlement" of non-whites.

The party's leader, Nick Griffin, has said the BNP is not racist and that the manifesto is not a "whites only" document.

But Prime Minister Tony Blair said the BNP's views were "completely abhorrent".

And Conservative leader Michael Howard said the party's policies were "totally unacceptable".

'Racial hatred'

The BNP's manifesto, to be launched on Monday, says the party would "introduce a policy of voluntary resettlement for those of our racial kin who wish to return to their ancestral homelands".

It adds: "This will not be forced on anyone, but those who choose to take up the offer will be given all necessary assistance."

The manifesto also pledges to "stop all further immigration and to deport all illegal immigrants".

Mr Griffin has insisted the BNP is not racist and has accused the media of misrepresenting the party.

"The BBC and other media organisations have been trying to portray the BNP as a racist party," he told the BBC News website.

"But our policies are not racist. We are not trying to persecute or victimise any particular group."

Mr Griffin said the BNP was "not a whites only party" and that it welcomed "people of all races and creeds who put Britain first".

'Abhorrent views'

But Mr Blair said the party's views were "completely abhorrent".

"I think it is important that people understand what this party stands for," he said.

"It is a party based on racial hatred, religious bigotry and intolerance.

"That is why it is important that people understand what they are voting for if they vote for this party."

Mr Howard said the BNP's policies were "totally unacceptable".

"I think it is very important that people understand that if they vote for the BNP they are not voting for a mainstream party," he said.

"They are voting for a party that is racist, a party that is anti-Semitic, a party that is homophobic."

Winn-Dixie, one of the largest supermarket chains in the US, has filed for bankruptcy.

The company said it would close 94 stores and cut 2,000 jobs as part of a restructuring plan.

Winn-Dixie, which has been struggling with debt, said it would focus on its remaining 485 stores in the southeastern US.

It is the latest US retailer to be hit by the economic downturn and competition from online rivals.

Winn-Dixie, which was founded in 1925, has been struggling in recent years as consumers have shifted to buying more food online and from discount stores.

The company has been trying to reinvent itself by renovating stores and expanding its online presence.

But those efforts have not been enough to offset the decline in sales.

Winn-Dixie's same-store sales have fallen for eight straight quarters.

The company said it would close 94 stores in the next 60 days. It did not say which stores would be closing.

The job cuts will come from corporate and store positions.

Winn-Dixie said it had secured $560m in financing from its lenders to help it through the bankruptcy process.

The company said it expected to emerge from bankruptcy within 90 days.

Napster has announced a new subscription service that will allow users to download and play rented music on portable devices.

The service, called Napster To Go, will cost $14.95 (8.30) a month in the US. It will initially work with Microsoft's Windows Media Player 10 software.

The move is seen as an attempt by the company to compete with Apple's iTunes Music Store, which sells songs for 99 cents each.

Napster's chief executive, Chris Gorog, said the service would offer "unlimited access to the entire Napster catalogue".

"This is a natural evolution for Napster," he said.

"We are giving our subscribers the ability to take their music with them wherever they go, without having to purchase or download each song individually."

The service will launch in the US on 16 December. It is not yet clear when or if it will be available in the UK.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve

Sir Alex Ferguson has praised Manchester United's "resilience" as they prepare to face Liverpool in Sunday's Premier League clash.

The Red Devils are currently second in the table, four points behind leaders Chelsea, and have lost just once in the league this season.

And Ferguson believes his side have shown great character to bounce back from that defeat to Newcastle and continue their push for the title.

"It was a big disappointment to lose at Newcastle but, to be fair to the team, they've responded in the right way," Ferguson told MUTV.

"They've shown a lot of resilience and they're all working hard to make sure we get the right results.

"When you look at the table, it's very tight at the top. I think it's inevitable that there will be slip-ups along the way but, hopefully, not too many."

Ferguson also had words of praise for United's top scorer this season, Robin van Persie, who has netted 15 goals in the league so far.

"He's been absolutely brilliant," said the Scot. "His goals and general all-round play have been first-class.

"It's not just his goals, though. It's his work-rate, his movement and his unselfish play. He's been a joy to watch."

The Liberal Democrats have appointed a new head of PR to spearhead their general election campaign.

Lucy Powell, who was director of communications for Ed Miliband's leadership campaign, will be the party's first female head of communications.

She will report directly to Nick Clegg and will be responsible for the party's media strategy during the election.

The move comes as the Lib Dems prepare to launch their election manifesto next week.

Ms Powell, who has also worked as a political adviser to former Labour deputy leader Harriet Harman, said she was "delighted" to be joining the party.

"The Liberal Democrats are in a unique position in this election and I am looking forward to working with the team to make the most of that," she said.

Mr Clegg said Ms Powell would be a "huge asset" to the party.

"She has a wealth of experience and I am confident that she will lead our communications operation with skill and energy," he said.

Greg Rusedski has questioned why the Lawn Tennis Association are not doing more to investigate the case of coach Dantechniche.

Rusedski, who has just appointed a new coach, is angry that the LTA have not spoken to him about the controversy.

Dantechniche is alleged to have supplied illegal performance-enhancing drugs to players.

The LTA say they are taking the claims "very seriously" but have not launched an investigation.

Rusedski, who has not been accused of wrongdoing, said: "I have appointed a new coach and I would like the LTA to speak to him.

"I don't understand why they haven't done anything. They are supposed to be the governing body."

The LTA said they would be "liaising closely" with the Tennis Anti-Doping Programme over the claims.

The Bafta Film Awards are taking place in London on Sunday, with Joaquin Phoenix and Renee Zellweger among the favourites to win.

Phoenix is up for best actor for his role in Joker, while Zellweger is nominated for best actress for her portrayal of Judy Garland in Judy.

The ceremony, hosted by Graham Norton, will be held at the Royal Albert Hall.

The awards are voted for by 6,500 Bafta members, who include actors, directors and other film industry professionals.

The full list of nominees is available on the Bafta website.

China's central bank has raised the amount of reserves that banks must hold for the third time in four months, in a bid to cool inflation.

The reserve requirement ratio will go up by half a percentage point to 17.5% from 15% from 5 December, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) said.

Prices in China have been rising at an annual rate of almost 6% in recent months.

The central bank has also hiked interest rates four times since October last year.

The latest move comes just a day after the government reported that inflation had hit a 28-month high of 5.1% in October.

Food prices, which have a big impact on inflation, were up 10.1% from a year earlier.

The latest figures have added to fears that inflation could become a problem for China's economy.

The central bank said it wanted to "further raise the intensity of macro-control" and would continue to use a "prudent" monetary policy.

It also called on local authorities to do more to control prices.

The move is likely to slow the Chinese economy, which grew by 10.3% in the third quarter.

But analysts say it is still likely to grow rapidly next year, helped by strong exports.

Football Association was investigating a complaint about comments made by Mourinho to media after their defeat by Southampton on Saturday.

"The FA has ended its investigation into an incident involving Jose Mourinho and has withdrawn its request for him to attend an face-to-face meeting," said a spokesman.

Mourinho had apologised for his comments, saying he was "wrong".

Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll and Australia's George Gregan will lead a star-studded line-up of rugby union players in a charity match in Dublin on Saturday.

The game, which will raise funds for the Irish Rugby Union's Injured Players Fund, will see a World XV take on an Ireland XV.

Other big names taking part include England's Jonny Wilkinson, Wales' Gavin Henson and New Zealand's Dan Carter.

"It's a great opportunity to see some of the biggest names in world rugby going head-to-head," said O'Driscoll.

"It will be a great occasion and hopefully we can raise a lot of money for a very worthy cause."

The match will take place at the Aviva Stadium, which is the home of Irish rugby, and will kick off at 14:30 GMT.

Car giant hit by Mercedes slump

DaimlerChrysler has announced a big drop in profits, blaming it on a fall in demand for its Mercedes-Benz cars.

The German-American carmaker said net profit in the April-to-June period slumped to 546 million euros ($642m; 358m) from 1.37 billion euros a year earlier.

Revenues were down 6% to 36.3 billion euros.

DaimlerChrysler said the fall in demand for its Mercedes cars was the main reason for the drop in profits.

"The significant decline in earnings is attributable primarily to the deterioration in the market environment for passenger cars of the Mercedes-Benz brand," the company said.

It added that it was expecting further pressure on profits in the second half of the year.

The European Commission has called for a clampdown on fraud against EU institutions, including foreign bribery, money laundering, and corruption.

In a report published on Wednesday, the commission said the scale of the problem was "significant" and urged member states to do more to tackle it.

The report said that, in the past five years, there had been more than 1,000 cases of fraud involving EU funds, with a total value of 1.6bn (1.3bn).

It also highlighted a number of cases of corruption and fraud in EU institutions, including the European Parliament, the European Commission, and the European Court of Auditors.

The commission said member states should set up a common definition of what constitutes a crime against the EU, and establish a mechanism to exchange information on suspected cases.

It also called for the setting up of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which would have the power to investigate and prosecute cases of EU fraud.

The Bush administration has proposed deep cuts in social programmes in its annual budget request to Congress.

The $4.1tn (2.2tn) spending plan for fiscal year 2009 would slash funding for healthcare, education and housing.

It would also make major changes to the tax code, including eliminating the estate tax and reducing the top rate for capital gains and dividends.

The proposal is unlikely to be passed by a Democrat-controlled Congress.

The budget request was unveiled as the US economy showed further signs of weakness, with the government reporting a sharp drop in retail sales in January.

'Tough choices'

The budget would increase defence spending by $48bn to $515bn, and homeland security by $2.2bn to $46.5bn.

It would also make $196bn in cuts to domestic programmes, including $28bn from healthcare and $5.6bn from education.

The administration says the cuts are needed to reduce the federal deficit, which is projected to reach $407bn in the next fiscal year.

"This budget makes the tough choices necessary to put America on a path to long-term fiscal responsibility," said White House budget director Jim Nussle.

But Democrats say the budget does not do enough to help struggling families and would make it harder for the poor to access healthcare and education.

"The president's budget is an irresponsible, ideological document that abandons any pretence of fiscal responsibility," said House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

The budget proposal is likely to face stiff opposition in the Senate, where Democrats have a slim majority.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid said the budget was "dead on arrival".

The budget request will now be considered by Congress, which will make its own spending recommendations before passing a final budget.

GlaxoSmithKline has announced a major restructuring that it says will lead to job losses and the sale of some businesses.

The company said the changes would help it to focus on its three main businesses - pharmaceuticals, vaccines and consumer healthcare.

It also announced a fall in annual profits, blaming the cost of restructuring and lower sales of some key drugs.

Under the plans, Glaxo will create two new divisions - one for pharmaceuticals and one for vaccines and consumer healthcare.

The company said the changes would lead to "significant" job losses, but did not give any details.

Glaxo said the restructuring would cost it 1.6bn over the next three years, but would save it 500m a year by 2021.

The company also announced a fall in annual profits, from 8.1bn to 7.6bn.

However, it said sales had risen by 2% to 30.6bn, thanks to strong demand for its vaccines and consumer healthcare products.

Rafa Benitez has warned Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard that he will not tolerate any more slip-ups from him.

The Spaniard was unhappy with Gerrard's performance in the 2-2 draw with Birmingham on Saturday and has told him he must improve.

"I was not happy with Steven's performance against Birmingham and I have told him that," said Benitez.

"I have spoken to him about it and he knows he has to do better. He is our captain and our leader and he has to set the example.

"I know he can do better and I am sure he will do better in the future."

Benitez also had words of praise for Gerrard's team-mate Jamie Carragher, who he believes is one of the best defenders in the world.

"Jamie Carragher is one of the best defenders in the world," said Benitez.

"He is so professional and he is so important to this team. He is a great player and a great person."

British Prime Minister Tony Blair has welcomed a deal between Turkey and the European Union which will allow long-stalled membership talks to begin.

The agreement, reached after two days of tough negotiations in Luxembourg, will see Turkey start the talks on 3 October.

Mr Blair said the deal was "good for Turkey, good for Europe and good for the world".

But he acknowledged that there were "still some difficult issues to be negotiated".

The agreement came after a marathon meeting of EU foreign ministers, which ended in the early hours of Friday morning.

Under the deal, Turkey will only be able to join the EU if it meets the same criteria as any other candidate country.

The talks are not expected to be completed for at least a decade.

Mr Blair said the agreement was "a very important step forward".

"It is good for Turkey, good for Europe and good for the world that Turkey is taking its rightful place as a candidate for membership of the European Union," he said.

"There are still some difficult issues to be negotiated. But the important thing is that the negotiations are now beginning and I believe they will be successful."

The agreement was reached after a last-minute compromise between France and Germany, who had been at loggerheads over the issue.

Under the deal, Turkey will only be able to join the EU if it meets the same criteria as any other candidate country.

The talks are not expected to be completed for at least a decade.

Mr Blair said the agreement was "a very important step forward".

"It is good for Turkey, good for Europe and good for the world that Turkey is taking its rightful place as a candidate for membership of the European Union," he said.

"There are still some difficult issues to be negotiated. But the important thing is that the negotiations are now beginning and I believe they will be successful."

The agreement was reached after a last-minute compromise between France and Germany, who had been at loggerheads over the issue.

The Nasdaq Stock Market is planning a $100m (61m) share sale, according to a filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

The move comes as Nasdaq announced it would delist the shares of three companies that have failed to meet listing requirements.

Nasdaq said the share sale would help it "meet future capital requirements".

The sale would represent a 3.4% stake in the company.

Nasdaq's decision to sell shares comes as the stock market operator is facing increased competition from rival exchanges.

Earlier this month, Nasdaq lost the battle to buy the New York Stock Exchange to its rival, IntercontinentalExchange (ICE).

The anti-spam screensaver, which was designed to help reduce the amount of junk mail being sent, has been scrapped.

The software, developed by a team at the University of California, worked by simulating the effects of spam on a computer's performance.

It was hoped that the screensaver would educate people about the negative effects of spam and encourage them to be more careful about what emails they opened.

However, the team has now decided to abandon the project after finding that the screensaver did not have a significant impact on people's behaviour.

The news comes as a blow to those who have been campaigning against spam, which is estimated to cost businesses billions of dollars each year.

Despite the setback, the team is still hopeful that its research will help to raise awareness of the issue and contribute to the development of more effective anti-spam measures in the future.

German growth goes into reverse

The German economy shrank in the final three months of last year, official figures have confirmed, as the eurozone crisis took its toll.

Gross domestic product (GDP) fell by 0.2% in the fourth quarter, compared with the previous three months.

The German economy had been growing steadily throughout 2011, but the eurozone debt crisis hit exports in the final months of the year.

The figures confirm a preliminary estimate released last month.

For the whole of 2011, the German economy grew by 3%, compared with 5.1% in 2010.

'Tough year'

The German economy is the largest in the eurozone, and its health is seen as crucial to the bloc's prospects.

"The German economy had a tough year in 2011," said Destatis, the federal statistics office.

"The main reasons for this were the euro crisis, which intensified in the second half of the year, and the high level of oil prices."

The figures come a day after the European Commission slashed its growth forecast for the eurozone as a whole in 2012.

It now expects the 17-nation bloc to shrink by 0.3% this year, compared with its previous forecast of 1% growth.

LONDON, June 11, 2021 (UPI) -- A newly discovered film reel shot by legendary painter Vincent van Gogh is set to be shown to the public for the first time later this month, the BBC reports.

The film, titled "The Hitchhiking Post Impressionist," was found by a Dutch film historian in an old box of van Gogh's belongings. It is believed to be the only known film created by the artist.

"The Hitchhiking Post Impressionist" is a short black-and-white film that shows van Gogh hitchhiking along a road in the Dutch countryside. The film was shot in the summer of 1890, just months before van Gogh's death.

The public will be able to see "The Hitchhiking Post Impressionist" at the EYE Film Institute in Amsterdam on June 25.

T-Mobile is betting that business users will be willing to pay a little more for a phone that doubles as a mini office.

The company has launched a new range of business-friendly smartphones, running Microsoft's Windows Mobile software.

The phones come with features such as the ability to view and edit Microsoft Office documents, as well as access company email and calendars.

T-Mobile is the first mobile operator in the UK to offer such a service.

The phones - which include the HTC TyTN, HTC S620 and MDA Vario III - will be available from free on business contracts.

T-Mobile said the phones were aimed at "mobile professionals who need access to their work life while on the move".

Microsoft's Windows Mobile software has been available on smartphones for some time, but this is the first time it has been offered by a UK mobile operator.

Piero Della Francesca, the great Italian Renaissance artist, died 500 years ago this month.

But his work is as relevant today as it was then, according to one of his countrymen.

Domenico Pieri is the president of Rugby Calvisano, one of Italy's leading clubs.

He believes the game can learn a lot from the way Della Francesca approached his paintings.

"Piero Della Francesca was a great humanist and a great artist," Pieri told BBC Sport.

"He was someone who looked at the world in a different way and he had a different perspective.

"I think rugby can learn from that. We need to have a different perspective on the game."

Pieri believes that rugby in Italy is at a crossroads and that the game must change if it is to progress.

"We are at a turning point in Italian rugby," he said.

"We need to decide whether we want to be a top-level rugby nation or not.

"If we want to be a top-level rugby nation, we need to change the way we approach the game.

"We need to have a different perspective."

Microsoft is to make changes to the way its Windows operating system handles piracy in a bid to shore up revenues.

The company will now require users to enter a product key during the set-up process of the OS.

Previously, users were given the option of skipping that step, and Microsoft said that many did so because they were using pirated copies of the software.

The new measure is aimed at reducing the number of counterfeit copies of Windows in use.

"This change will help ensure customers receive all the rights and benefits they are entitled to when they purchase genuine Microsoft software," the company said in a statement.

The company did not say when the changes would come into effect.

Microsoft has been struggling to combat the spread of pirated copies of its software, particularly in developing countries.

Earlier this year, the company said that about one in three copies of Windows in use around the world were not properly licensed.

The problem has been compounded by the increasing popularity of so-called "grey market" software, which is genuine but sold at a much lower price than the official retail versions.

Singer-songwriter custardphoenix created a song called Shooting Stars to remember the victims of the Orlando nightclub shooting, and has been met with an outpouring of support from the LGBTQ community.

The track has been backed by fellow musician Lady Knight, who praised custardphoenix for their "powerful" lyrics.

In an open letter posted on social media, custardphoenix said they had been "humbled and overwhelmed" by the response to the song.

Shooting Stars was written in the aftermath of the Pulse nightclub shooting in Orlando, Florida, which left 49 people dead and 53 injured.

The song starts with the lines: "We are all made of love and light/ But sometimes the darkness creeps in/ And it's hard to see the signs/ When the hatred comes alive."

It goes on to say: "But we won't let them win/ We'll keep on dancing/ We'll keep on fighting/ For our lives."

In their letter, custardphoenix said they had been "moved to tears" by messages of support from the LGBTQ community.

"Your messages of love, hope and solidarity are what keep me going when the hate feels too loud," they wrote.

 Lady Knight, who is also a member of the LGBTQ community, shared the song on social media and praised custardphoenix for their "powerful" lyrics.

"This song is so beautiful and so needed," she wrote. "Thank you for your courage in sharing it."

The Orlando shooting was the deadliest mass shooting in modern US history and the deadliest terror attack on US soil since 9/11.

Elvis fans from around the world have been celebrating the King's 75th birthday with a special bash in Memphis, Tennessee.

Around 1,500 fans attended the event, which featured live music, Elvis impersonators and a birthday cake.

Organisers say it was the biggest Elvis birthday celebration ever held.

Fans came from as far afield as Australia, Japan, Brazil and the UK to attend the three-day event.

On Saturday, they took part in a candlelit vigil at Elvis's grave in Graceland.

The event ended on Sunday with a gospel brunch, featuring live music and a special performance by Elvis's former wife, Priscilla Presley.

The former head of the civil service has denied he was "leant on" by Downing Street to change his advice to ministers on the legality of the Iraq war.

Lord Goldsmith said he had been asked for his opinion "on a number of occasions" but it was "entirely a matter for me".

He was speaking after the publication of the Chilcot Inquiry into the 2003 invasion.

The report said Tony Blair had overstated the case for war and sent ill-prepared troops into battle.

Lord Goldsmith, who was attorney general at the time, initially advised that an invasion would be illegal without a fresh UN resolution - but later changed his mind.

In his first public comments since the publication of the Chilcot report, he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that the decision on whether to go to war was "a political one".

"The role of the attorney general is to advise on the lawfulness of military action and that is what I did," he said.

"I was asked for my opinion on a number of occasions, as the report makes clear, and it was entirely a matter for me what advice I gave and when I gave it."

He added: "I was not leant on in any way whatsoever."

Lord Goldsmith also defended his decision to change his mind on the legality of the war, saying he had been presented with "new information" which led him to conclude that there was a "reasonable case" for military action.

"The advice I gave at the end of March 2003 was based on the information that was available to me at that time," he said.

"Subsequently, new information came to light, in particular from the UN Secretary General Kofi Annan, which led me to conclude that there was a reasonable case that the use of force against Iraq in these circumstances could be lawful."

He added: "I'm not going to go into the detail of that now, but that is what led me to change my advice."

French President Jacques Chirac has said the UK's rebate from the European Union is "unjustified" and should be scrapped.

Speaking at a joint news conference with German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder, Mr Chirac said the UK's rebate - worth about 3bn a year - was a "relic" of the past.

Mr Schroeder said he agreed with Mr Chirac, but added that any reform of the rebate should not come at the expense of other EU countries.

The UK has always said it will only give up its rebate - negotiated by Margaret Thatcher in 1984 - if there are reforms to the EU's common agricultural policy.

Mr Chirac's comments are likely to increase tensions between the UK and France ahead of a key EU summit in June, where leaders will discuss the bloc's budget for 2007-2013.

The UK is the biggest net contributor to the EU budget, and pays about 8bn a year more than it gets back in subsidies and other payments.

The rebate is worth about 3bn a year to the UK, and means the country pays about 5bn a year into the EU pot.

Mr Chirac said the rebate was "unjustified" and should be scrapped, adding that it was a "relic" of the past which no longer made sense.

"It is an anachronism which should be done away with," he said.

Mr Schroeder said he agreed with Mr Chirac, but added that any reform of the rebate should not come at the expense of other EU countries.

The UK has always said it will only give up its rebate - negotiated by Margaret Thatcher in 1984 - if there are reforms to the EU's common agricultural policy.

Mr Chirac's comments are likely to increase tensions between the UK and France ahead of a key EU summit in June, where leaders will discuss the bloc's budget for 2007-2013.

India's largest carmaker Maruti Suzuki has reported a nearly two-fold jump in quarterly profit, boosted by strong demand for its vehicles.

Net profit rose to 9.4 billion rupees ($142 million) in the quarter to the end of September, from 4.9 billion rupees a year earlier.

Sales rose 14% to 159.3 billion rupees during the period.

The company, which has a market share of around 50% in India, said it sold 312,ibles during the quarter, up from 276,584 units a year earlier.

Maruti Suzuki, which is majority-owned by Japan's Suzuki Motor, has been benefiting from a growing economy and rising affluence in India.

However, the company has been facing some challenges of late, including labour unrest at its factory in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.

A new Japanese film is to get a global release after becoming a huge box office hit in its home country.

The movie is called "Your Name" and it has already made more than $180m (140m) in Japan.

It is a story about two teenagers who live in different parts of the country.

They start to have strange dreams about each other and then they start to swap places.

The film's director, Makoto Shinkai, said he never expected the film to be such a success.

"When we were making the film, we were only thinking about how to make a good film," he said.

"We never thought it would become this big."

"Your Name" is due to be released in the UK on 24 February.

Sainsbury's has donated 1m to the Labour Party, it has been announced.

The supermarket giant said the donation was made "in recognition of the party's commitment to the living wage".

The move comes as Labour leader Ed Miliband prepares to unveil his party's election manifesto on Monday.

A Sainsbury's spokesman said: "We have always been clear that we support the living wage."

The donation was made on Friday, the day after Mr Miliband announced plans to raise the minimum wage to 8 by 2020 if Labour wins the general election.

The party said the move would benefit more than five million workers and would be funded by a tax on properties worth more than 2m.

The Sainsbury's spokesman said: "We believe that the Labour Party's plans for the minimum wage are the right ones for business and for our customers."

The donation was criticised by the Conservatives, with party chairman Grant Shapps saying it showed that Labour was "in the pocket of the unions and big business".

"It is clear that Ed Miliband is too weak to stand up to the vested interests that bankroll his party," he said.

Labour said the donation showed that businesses were "backing our plans".

A party spokesman said: "This is further evidence that businesses are backing our plans to deliver a higher minimum wage, more apprenticeships and a better deal for consumers."

Mozilla is today offering its Firefox web browser as a free download in a bid to steal market share from Microsoft's dominant Internet Explorer software. The new version of Firefox has been downloaded more than 10 million times since its launch in November, Mozilla claims.

Firefox has been aggressively marketed as a more secure alternative to IE and a string of vulnerabilities in Microsoft's software has helped its cause. However, IE still holds around 80% of the browser market.

"We're not trying to put Microsoft out of business, we're just trying to level the playing field," said Mitchell Baker, chairman of the Mozilla Foundation.

"They (Microsoft) have an incredible monopoly position and they deploy that monopoly position in ways that aren't fair," she told the BBC.

The latest version of Firefox includes a spell-checker, improvements to tabbed browsing and support for Microsoft's ActiveX technology.

Mozilla is a non-profit organisation and the Firefox browser is largely the work of a team of volunteer developers.

The full article can be found at:

http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4133264.stm

Slovakia have reached the Hopman Cup final for the first time after defeating the United States in the semi-finals.

Dominika Cibulkova and Andrej Martin beat Madison Keys and Jack Sock 6-4 6-3 in the mixed doubles to seal victory.

Cibulkova had earlier beaten Keys 6-4 6-2 in the singles, with Sock defeating Martin 6-3 6-4.

Slovakia will face either Australia or Switzerland in Sunday's final.

Cibulkova, who is ranked 10th in the world, was in dominant form against Keys, who is ranked seventh.

The Slovakian won the first set 6-4 and then raced into a 5-0 lead in the second set before Keys finally got on the scoreboard.

Cibulkova then served out the match to secure victory in straight sets.

Sock, who is ranked 22nd in the world, then took on Martin in the singles and won in straight sets to level the tie at 1-1.

However, Cibulkova and Martin proved too strong in the mixed doubles, winning 6-4 6-3 to seal victory for Slovakia.

Former MP George Galloway has urged the release of a British freelance photographer held hostage in Afghanistan.

Speaking during a visit to Kabul, Mr Galloway said it was "in the interests of everybody" that the captors freed the man.

The politician, who is a member of the Respect Party, was visiting the country as part of a fact-finding mission.

The photographer was abducted by the Taliban in March and has not been heard from since.

Mr Galloway, who has been critical of the British military presence in Afghanistan, said he did not know the circumstances surrounding the man's capture.

But he said he had been "led to believe" the captors were holding him in the hope of securing the release of Taliban prisoners.

"I appeal to the Taliban today - or whoever is holding our countryman - to let him go," said Mr Galloway.

"It is not serving anybody's interests that a person from our country is being held against his will."

Mr Galloway said he believed the Taliban were gaining in strength and that the war in Afghanistan was "unwinnable".

"The time has come to enter into a dialogue with the Afghan resistance," he said.

The politician is due to meet President Hamid Karzai during his visit.

Satellite mapping is helping aid agencies in Sudan's Darfur region to plan their work more effectively, the UN says.

The technology is being used to produce high-resolution images of the region, which can be used to plan the distribution of aid.

The UN says the mapping will help it to target areas most in need of assistance.

More than two million people have been displaced by conflict in Darfur since 2003.

The UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said the satellite images would help it to plan the distribution of aid more effectively.

"This is the first time that we have had such high-resolution imagery of Darfur," said OCHA spokesman Jens Laerke.

"It will help us to target areas most in need of assistance, and to plan the distribution of aid more effectively."

The images, which have a resolution of two metres, were taken by the WorldView-2 satellite operated by US company DigitalGlobe.

They show the location of roads, villages and camps for internally displaced people (IDPs).

The UN says more than two million people have been displaced by conflict in Darfur since 2003

OCHA said the images would be made available to all aid agencies working in Darfur.

The conflict in Darfur began in 2003 when ethnic African rebels took up arms against the Arab-dominated Sudanese government, accusing it of marginalising the region.

The UN says more than 300,000 people have been killed and more than two million displaced since then.

British companies are pumping billions of pounds into their pension schemes despite the coronavirus pandemic.

Data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed that 43 FTSE 100 firms contributed a total of 13.7bn to their pensions in the first three months of 2020.

That is up from 11.3bn in the same period last year.

Pension experts said the increase was partly due to firms catching up on contributions that were deferred during the pandemic.

The ONS data showed that the contributions were made by firms including British Airways, Barclays, GlaxoSmithKline, Lloyds Banking Group, Reckitt Benckiser and Royal Dutch Shell.

It comes as many firms are facing tough decisions over where to cut costs as the pandemic continues to hit their businesses.

"Despite the pandemic, a number of large employers appear to have made significant pensions contributions in the first quarter of this year," said Bryn Jones, chief investment officer at Royal London Asset Management.

"This is likely to be in part due to 'catch-up' payments, following a period in which some companies deferred or skipped pension contributions altogether."

But he warned that the pension deficit for FTSE 350 firms had risen to 75bn in the first quarter of the year, from 61bn at the end of 2019.

"This is likely to be down to the fall in asset values as a result of the pandemic," he said.

"The pensions situation for UK companies is still very challenging and many will be looking at how they can reduce their costs."

The Manic Street Preachers are to take over BBC 6 Music for a day.

The Welsh band will present shows on the digital radio station on 19 December.

They will also play a live set in the 6 Music studios, which will be broadcast on the day.

The Manics said they were "huge fans" of 6 Music and were "honoured" to be asked to present a show.

"We've been massive fans of 6 Music since its inception," said the band in a statement.

"It's an honour to be asked to present a show and play a live set in the 6 Music studios."

The band's frontman James Dean Bradfield added: "6 Music has been a constant source of inspiration and support to us over the years."

The Manic Street Preachers will take over 6 Music from 09:00 GMT on 19 December.

The UK is heading in the wrong direction and risks becoming a "divided society", former Conservative leader Michael Howard has warned.

In a speech in London, he said the government was "failing to deliver" on key issues like immigration and the economy.

And he accused Theresa May of being "in denial" about the scale of the challenge facing the UK.

Mrs May has said the UK is "heading in the right direction" and that her government is "delivering on the people's priorities".

In his speech, Mr Howard said the UK was "heading in the wrong direction" and risked becoming a "divided society".

He said the government was "failing to deliver" on key issues like immigration and the economy.

And he accused Theresa May of being "in denial" about the scale of the challenge facing the UK.

Mrs May has said the UK is "heading in the right direction" and that her government is "delivering on the people's priorities".

It is reported that a German bidder is in talks with the London Stock Exchange about a possible takeover.

The German company, which has not been named, is said to be ready to offer more than 20bn for the LSE.

The Financial Times says the bid could come as early as this week.

The LSE has been the subject of takeover speculation for some time, with US Nasdaq seen as a potential bidder.

However, the LSE has consistently denied that it is up for sale.

In September, the LSE agreed to buy Refinitiv, the financial data business, for $27bn.

Manchester United are to open their books to the Glazer family as the American owners consider selling the club.

The Glazers, who bought United in 2005, have been in talks with several investment banks about the possibility of a sale.

It is understood United's executive vice-chairman Ed Woodward has been in the US this week to meet with the family.

The Glazers are believed to be considering their options after 15 years in charge.

The family took on significant debt to buy the club, and there has been fan unrest over the years about the level of investment in the team.

However, the club has been successful on the pitch under the Glazers, winning 13 trophies, including five Premier League titles, since they took over.

The Glazers are said to be aware of the interest from potential buyers and are now considering their options.

It is not clear how much the family would be looking for if they did decide to sell, but it is thought they would want to recoup the estimated 1.2bn they paid for the club.

The Glazers bought United for 790m in 2005, and the club is now worth an estimated 3bn.

Any sale of the club would be likely to be the biggest in British football history.

Band Aid 20 has stormed to the top of the UK singles chart, selling more than 300,000 copies in its first week.

The all-star charity record, which features the likes of Coldplay, Dido and Dizzee Rascal, is raising money for victims of the Ethiopian famine.

Last year's Band Aid 20 single, Do They Know It's Christmas?, sold more than 1.2 million copies.

The original 1984 version, featuring Bob Geldof and Bono, is the UK's third best-selling single of all time.

The new version of the song, which was recorded last month, features a new set of lyrics written by Take That's Gary Barlow.

It is the first time the song has been re-recorded since the original version in 1984.

The single is available to download now and will be released on CD on 29 November.

A US-based hacker has broken into T-Mobile's systems and accessed the personal data of around two million customers, the mobile operator has confirmed. The malicious intrusion was discovered on Monday, and T-Mobile says no financial data was accessed. However, a range of other information, including names, addresses, birthdates, Social Security numbers and other ID numbers was exposed. T-Mobile has informed the FBI and is now contacting affected customers. In a statement, the company called the data breach "absolutely unacceptable" and pledged to increase security measures. "We take the security of your information very seriously and have a number of safeguards in place to protect it," the statement said. "Unfortunately, no company's data is completely safe from sophisticated, dedicated hackers." The hacker, who goes by the name of "WeErAh"," claimed to have accessed the data through a vulnerability in T-Mobile's website. He posted some of the information online to prove his claim. It is not clear how long the breach went undetected. T-Mobile is the third-largest mobile operator in the US, with around 86 million customers.

The story of how a young Iraqi woman became an international blogging sensation is being made into a film.

The Iraqi news website Al-Monitor reports that the film, titled "Baghdad Blogger", is currently in production in Iraq.

The film is based on the book "IraQi Girl" by Maha Hassan, which tells the story of how the young woman, who uses the pseudonym "Riverbend", started writing a blog about life in Baghdad during the Iraq War.

The blog, which was started in 2003, quickly gained a large international following, and Riverbend became a symbol of the plight of ordinary Iraqis during the war.

The film is being directed by Mohamed al-Daradji, and will star Iraqi actress Wafaa al-Kalil as Riverbend.

It is not yet known when the film will be released.

The 2004 Bafta awards for computer games have been dominated by Half-Life 2, with the first-person shooter bagging five prizes.

The hit PC title picked up the Bafta for best game, as well as awards for audio achievement, design, multiplayer and original score.

Other big winners included Nintendo's The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, which won the animated graphics award.

The British Academy of Film and Television Arts also presented a special award to David Braben and Ian Bell, the creators of the 1984 game Elite.

Half-Life 2's development studio, Valve, was named best developer, while also winning an award for technical achievement for its Steam gaming platform.

The awards ceremony, held in London on Tuesday evening, was hosted by comedian Graham Norton.

John Lennon believes Hibernian will be underdogs against Rangers in Sunday's Scottish League Cup final.

The Hibs manager says his side are "massive outsiders" for the Ibrox showpiece and has challenged his players to prove the bookmakers wrong.

Lennon says he will take inspiration from Liverpool's underdog status before their Champions League final against AC Milan in 2005.

"It is a one-off game, anything can happen on the day," Lennon told BBC Scotland.

"It is a massive ask for us, I totally understand that, but it is one we are relishing and looking forward to.

"We are massive outsiders, there is no getting away from that. The bookmakers have us as 4-1, 5-1 underdogs but, again, that just adds to the motivation for the players.

"We have to accept that, understand that and use it as a positive rather than a negative.

"Liverpool were massive underdogs in the Champions League final against AC Milan and they went and won it. We have to try and take inspiration from that.

"It is a one-off game, anything can happen on the day. We are not going to roll over, that is for sure."

Lennon says he will make a late decision on whether to include Scotland striker Steven Fletcher in his matchday squad.

Fletcher, who has not played since August because of an ankle injury, has resumed full training but Lennon says he needs more time to assess the 23-year-old's fitness.

"He trained today (Thursday) and he will train tomorrow," said the Hibs boss. "He is chomping at the bit to play but, again, we have to be mindful of the re-occurrence of his injury.

"We don't want to take any unnecessary risks but, if he comes through the next two training sessions ok, then he will travel with us and be in the squad.

"If not, then he will continue to build up his match fitness with the reserves and hopefully be available for next week's game against Aberdeen."

The United Nations' food agency has warned that subsidies paid to farmers in developed countries are having a "distorting" effect on world markets.

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said in its annual report that such subsidies amounted to $258bn (160bn) in 2012.

It said this was more than double the $120bn spent on subsidies in developing countries.

The FAO said the subsidies were preventing developing countries from competing fairly.

"The high and rising levels of agricultural subsidies in developed countries are having a distorting effect on world markets," the agency said in its State of Food and Agriculture report.

"They are preventing developing countries from competing fairly in international markets and are a major barrier to their efforts to reduce hunger and poverty."

The FAO said that the subsidies were often used to support "inefficient" farmers, and called for them to be reformed.

It also called for greater investment in agriculture in developing countries, saying that this was essential to reducing hunger and poverty.

Labour is focusing on winning back support from its traditional voters as the general election campaign enters its final phase.

In a speech in central London, Chancellor Gordon Brown said a Conservative government would be a "disaster" for Britain.

He also accused the Lib Dems of being in bed with the Tories and said a Nigel Farage-led UKIP would take the UK out of the EU.

The Tories said Mr Brown was "flailing around".

With a week to go until polling day on 7 May, the latest opinion poll for the Sunday Times puts the Conservatives on 36%, ahead of Labour on 31% and the Lib Dems on 22/.

Labour is aiming to eat into the Tory lead by winning back voters who have drifted to UKIP or the Lib Dems over the past five years.

'Shrinking horizon'

In his speech, Mr Brown acknowledged many people were "disillusioned" with politics but urged them not to give up on the system.

He said the Conservatives would be a "disaster" for Britain, arguing they would make deep cuts to public spending and economic growth would stall as a result.

And he accused the Lib Dems of being in bed with the Tories, saying they would prop up a minority Conservative government in return for a "few token promises" on issues like voting reform.

He said UKIP was a "one-policy party" whose sole focus was taking Britain out of the European Union, warning this would be "a recipe for economic disaster".

Mr Brown said: "With just one week to go, Britain's future is at stake and the choice could not be clearer.

"A Labour government that will invest to grow our economy, protect our NHS and provide coherent, principled opposition to the Tories and Lib Dems.

"Or a shrinking Conservative horizon, in hock to the Lib Dems, taking Britain back to the 1930s with deeper cuts than those of the 1920s."

'Desperate'

The Conservatives said Mr Brown was a "desperate man flailing around" and accused him of making "false claims and conducting a personal vendetta" against their leader David Cameron.

A spokesman said: " Gordon Brown is becoming more and more desperate by the day. After five years of failed Gordon Brown economics, the last thing we need is five more.

"Only a vote for the Conservatives will give us the strong and stable government we need to secure the recovery and start to pay down

REM have announced a new Glasgow concert.

The American rock band will play the SSE Hydro on November 27, as part of their European tour.

Tickets for the show go on sale on Friday, September 27 at 9am.

REM last played in Glasgow in 2005, when they headlined the city's Hogmanay celebrations.

The band, who are best known for hits such as 'Losing My Religion' and 'Everybody Hurts', released their 15th studio album, 'Collapse Into Now', in 2011.

A Conservative candidate has quit the race to be the next London mayor after it emerged she had previously been a member of the BNP.

Shporting no longer seeking selection as Conservative mayoral candidate
