Lutfur Rahman has been the subject of intense scrutiny since he was branded "the unacceptable face of politics" by a judge in 2015.

During his successful campaign to be re-elected as mayor of Tower Hamlets, he was accused of using "undue spiritual influence" over the borough's large Bangladeshi community, linking up with controversial Islamic preacher Chowdhury Mueen-Uddin, and of improperly using public funds.

Rahman has denied any wrongdoing.

The European Union is aiming to increase its development aid budget by 50% over the next seven years.

The proposal, which will be discussed by EU leaders later this month, would see the bloc's development budget rise to 130bn (114bn; $145bn) by 2030.

The move comes as the EU looks to boost its global influence and meet its commitment to spend 0.7% of gross national income on development.

The proposal is likely to be opposed by some member states who are struggling to meet their own financial commitments.

The EU's current development budget is 86bn, with the majority of funds going to Africa.

The bloc says the increase would allow it to support an additional 500 million people out of poverty and help meet the UN's Sustainable Development Goals.

EU development commissioner Neven Mimica said the proposal was a "historic moment" for the bloc.

"The EU is today the world's leading donor of development assistance," he said.

"With this proposal, we are reaffirming our commitment to the world's poorest and most vulnerable people."

Elvis fans are holding a two-day birthday bash to celebrate what would have been the rock star's 80th birthday.

The event in Porthcawl, Wales, will feature live music, tribute acts and a lookalike competition.

Organiser Gareth Hampton said: "I'm a massive fan and have been since I was a child.

"I used to go down to the Four Aces club in Cardiff to watch the tribute acts and I thought, 'Why not bring something like that to Porthcawl?'

"It's grown from there. We've got people coming from all over the UK and even as far away as America."

Hampton, who runs a company that makes Elvis memorabilia, said he expected about 1,000 people to attend the event.

The birthday bash will take place at the Grand Pavilion on Friday and Saturday.

The Sundance Film Festival will pay tribute to cinema from around the world with a new award, organisers have announced.

The World Cinema Grand Jury Prize will be presented to two films at the Utah-based event, which runs from 18-28 January.

It will be the first time the festival, founded by Robert Redford in 1978, has had an award specifically for foreign-language films.

"These films reflect the diversity of voices and stories that independent film has to offer," said John Cooper, Sundance's director of programming.

"The Sundance Film Festival has always been a champion of films from outside the United States, and we are proud to honour them with this new award."

The prize for best drama will be decided by a jury of five film-makers, critics and industry figures, while the best documentary prize will be voted for by a separate five-person panel.

Both juries will be announced in December.

This is an important development for the Sundance Film Festival, which has been increasingly turning its focus to foreign films in recent years. The new award is a reflection of that trend, and is sure to be a popular addition to the festival.

A global day of action has been called by bloggers to protest against internet censorship.

The day of action, on 12 March, has been organised by a coalition of international blogging networks and online civil liberties groups.

They are calling on people to blog about internet freedom and to take part in online protests and petitions.

The move comes after a number of countries, including China, Iran and Saudi Arabia, have tightened controls on internet use.

"We are witnessing an unprecedented wave of internet censorship," said Peter Micek, of the US-based group Access Now, which is helping to organise the day of action.

"From India to Indonesia, from Turkey to Tajikistan, governments are increasingly using sophisticated technology to block access to information online and to silence dissent."

The coalition is also calling on people to sign a petition calling on world leaders to "support and protect internet freedom".

The petition has been signed by more than 100,000 people so far.

The day of action has been backed by a number of high-profile figures in the blogging world, including US-based blogger Anil Dash and UK-based writer and activist Laurie Penny.

Portishead, one of the most acclaimed trip-hop groups of the 1990s, are back with their first new album in eight years.

The band, whose third album "Third" was nominated for a Grammy, have been working on the follow-up for the past four years.

Guitarist Adrian Utley told the BBC the new record was "a lot more organic" than "Third".

"There are lots of live drums and bass and guitar," he said. "We've moved away from the kind of programmed beats that we were using last time."

The new album, which is yet to be given a title or release date, was recorded in a studio the band built themselves in a converted barn in rural England.

"It's very much a Portishead record," said Utley. "There are lots of melancholy songs, dark songs, sad songs, beautiful songs."

Lead singer Beth Gibbons, who has also released two solo albums since the last Portishead record, said the band was "really excited" to be back.

"We can't wait to play the new songs live," she said. "It feels like the right time to do it."

The band are due to headline the All Points East festival in London in May, and will also play headline shows in Manchester and Glasgow.

TV presenter Cat Deeley has dropped out of hosting Saturday morning show CD:UK.

Deeley, who has fronted the show since 2002, said she was leaving to concentrate on her US career.

"It's been an amazing three years and I've loved every minute," she said. "But now is the right time for me to move on."

Deeley will be replaced by former Atomic Kitten singer Liz McClarnon. The show's executive producer, Guy Freeman, said Deeley had been "a joy to work with".

"She has been a fantastic host and we all wish her the very best for the future," he added.

Deeley, 26, has hosted a number of shows in the US, including So You Think You Can Dance?.

She will continue to host the US version of CD:UK, which is shown on the Fox network.

Woodward eyes Brennan for Lions

Former England coach Sir Clive Woodward has targeted Wales scrum-half Mike Phillips as a potential replacement for the injured Andy Murray.

Woodward, who is now director of rugby at Bath, is also interested in signing Ireland fly-half Jonathan Sexton and Wales centre Jamie Roberts.

Brennan, 31, has been capped 37 times by Wales and was a member of the 2009 British and Irish Lions tour to South Africa.

Phillips, who is currently without a club, has also been linked with a move to Bath.

Former Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier has praised the current regime under Rafael Benitez.

Houllier, who led the Reds to a treble in 2001, told the club's official website: "What Rafa has done is fantastic.

"I think he has improved the team a lot. He has been very clever in the way he has approached his task."

Houllier also believes that Liverpool can still win the Premier League this season, despite being 12 points behind leaders Chelsea.

"It is a big, big gap but it is possible," he said. "If they can win their game in hand they will be only seven points behind Chelsea. That is not impossible."

Russia's chief negotiator in talks to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) says progress has been made in the latest round of negotiations.

 Mikhail Fradkov said the two sides had overcome some "sticking points" and that he was hopeful a deal could be reached by the end of the year.

Russia has been trying to join the WTO since the early 1990s.

The latest round of talks, which began on Monday, focused on the issue of agriculture.

Russia is the only major economy not to be a member of the WTO.

Membership would give it greater access to global markets and boost its economic growth.

'Positive signal'

Mr Fradkov said the latest round of talks, which ended on Friday, had been "constructive".

"I think that the results of the negotiations can be called positive," he was quoted as saying by the Interfax news agency.

"We have managed to overcome a number of sticking points."

He said the two sides had made progress on the issue of agriculture, which has been a key sticking point in the negotiations.

"This is a very positive signal that the negotiations are moving in the right direction," he said.

Mr Fradkov said he was hopeful that a deal could be reached by the end of the year, but cautioned that there was still "a lot of work to be done".

The next round of talks is due to take place in Geneva in September.

Howard and Blair tax pledge clash

Tony Blair and Michael Howard have clashed over tax in the first full-scale debate of the general election campaign. The two leaders traded blows over the economy and public services in a two-hour TV grilling.

Mr Blair insisted he would not put up taxes, while Mr Howard said he would not rule it out and accused the PM of "lying" about his plans. The Lib Dems' Charles Kennedy said both men were "ducking" the issue.

The economy and public services

Mr Blair and Mr Howard went head-to-head over the economy and public services

The two leaders were put under intense questioning from a studio audience of 100 people in Manchester, with the economy and public services high on the agenda.

Mr Blair insisted the government had increased investment in public services, while Mr Howard said it had wasted money and failed to deliver.

The Conservative leader said he would not rule out raising taxes to pay for his plans to increase investment in public services, saying it would be "irresponsible" to do so.

But Mr Blair accused him of "lying" about the Tories' plans, saying they would lead to 35bn of cuts.

The Lib Dem leader said both men were "ducking" the issue of tax, and accused them of making "unfunded promises".

Iraq

The two leaders also clashed over the war in Iraq, with Mr Howard accusing the prime minister of "misleading" the country over the reasons for going to war.

Mr Blair said the war had been "right" but admitted that the intelligence on Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction had been "wrong".

He said the world was a "better place" without Saddam in power, but conceded that the war had made the UK a "target" for terrorism.

Mr Howard said the war had been a "distraction" from the fight against terrorism and accused the prime minister of "rushing" into it without a proper plan.

The Lib Dem leader said the war had been a "catastrophe" and accused the two main parties of "ducking" the issue.

The environment

Fightstar took to the stage at the Reading Festival on Sunday night, just hours after it was announced that the band's drummer, Omar Abidi, had died.

The band paid tribute to Abidi, who died aged 28, with a moment of silence before their set.

Frontman Charlie Simpson told the crowd: "We want to dedicate this show to our brother Omar. We love you so much and we'll miss you forever."

The band played a set of their hits, including "We Apologise for Nothing", "Palahniuk's Laughter" and "Deathcar".

Simpson also paid tribute to Linkin Park's Chester Bennington, who died last week.

"I know a lot of people in this crowd will have been affected by Chester's passing," he said.

"He was an incredible artist and an incredible human being, and he is going to be missed by so many people."

Prime Minister Tony Blair has signalled that the government is now focusing on the general election, due within the next year.

In an article for the Sunday Times, he said the government had achieved a lot but there was still more to do.

And he pledged to fight the election on the NHS, schools and crime - the three issues he said mattered most to voters.

The election is expected to be held in May 2005.

UK Coal has reported a bigger annual loss after being hit by falling coal prices and production problems.

The miner made a pre-tax loss of 71.3m in the year to the end of December, compared with a 52.9m loss in 2011.

Revenue fell by 33.1m to 547.4m, as coal prices dropped by about 15% and production was hit by a fire at one of its mines.

The company said it was "disappointed" with the results but was taking steps to cut costs.

'Significant challenges'

UK Coal is the country's largest coal producer, and supplies about 6% of the coal used in power stations.

It said the fall in coal prices had been driven by a combination of factors, including a mild winter, which reduced demand, and increased competition from cheaper gas.

The company's production was also hit by a fire at its Daw Mill mine in Warwickshire in July, which forced its closure.

The fire caused about 40m of damage, and the company said it would not reopen the mine.

UK Coal said it was taking steps to cut costs, including reducing the number of its employees by about 10%.

It is also selling some of its non-core assets, and is in talks with the government about the possibility of converting some of its mines to produce gas.

"The group faces significant challenges," said chief executive Kevin McCullough.

"However, we are taking decisive action to address these, and are confident that the group has a viable future."

US cyber security chief resigns

The US cyber security chief has resigned, days after a major hack of federal government agencies.

Chris Krebs was appointed by President Donald Trump in 2017 to lead the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA).

But he was fired by Mr Trump last week via Twitter, after he disputed the president's claims of election fraud.

In a statement on Tuesday, Mr Krebs said it had been "the honour of a lifetime" to serve at CISA.

"I am proud of what we have accomplished together in making our nation more secure from cyber and physical threats," he said.

"There is much more work to do to ensure our nation's networks and critical infrastructure are protected from malicious actors."

Mr Krebs' departure comes amid a major shake-up of the US government's cyber security apparatus, following the hack of several federal agencies.

The hack, which was first reported last week, is believed to have been carried out by Russia.

Mr Trump has downplayed the seriousness of the hack, and on Tuesday he again accused Mr Krebs of being "highly inaccurate".

In a tweet, the president said Mr Krebs' firing was "well deserved".

Ireland can win the Grand Slam, according to former England captain Martin Johnson.

"They have got the squad to do it," Johnson told BBC Radio 5 live.

"They have got the belief and they have got the coach in Joe Schmidt, who has instilled that belief in them."

Ireland have won their last 11 Tests, including a record-equalling 18-match winning run, and are unbeaten in the Six Nations since losing to England in 2015.

"They are a very, very good team," said Johnson.

"They are very well-coached, they have got good players and they believe in themselves.

"When you have got that, you have got a chance."

Ireland face England at Twickenham on 17 March in their final game of the championship.

The makers of Wife Swap are suing the US network ABC for $30m (15m), claiming it copied the show.

RDF Media, which makes the UK reality TV programme, says ABC's Wife Swap USA is "substantially and strikingly similar" to its own show.

It says the US version, which began in September 2004, uses the same format, music and graphics.

ABC has not yet commented on the lawsuit, which was filed in a Los Angeles court on Monday.

Wife Swap, which began on Channel 4 in the UK in 2003, sees two mothers from different families swap lives for two weeks.

The show has been a huge success in the UK, and has been sold to more than 100 countries.

RDF Media says it has been in talks with ABC about the US show since March 2004, but the talks broke down in August.

The UK company is now seeking damages and an injunction to stop ABC from broadcasting Wife Swap USA.

The government and the DUP were close to agreeing a deal to prop up Theresa May's minority government, it has been claimed.

However, the deal reportedly faltered over the role of former Prime Minister Sir Edward Heath in the 1974 Northern Ireland power-sharing executive.

The BBC understands the DUP was unhappy with the level of information being provided about Sir Edward's role.

The government has been seeking the support of the DUP's 10 MPs to get its Queen's Speech and key Brexit legislation through Parliament.

The DUP has been in talks with the government since the general election, in which the Conservatives lost their majority.

A deal between the two parties would see the DUP back the government on key votes in Parliament, in return for extra investment in Northern Ireland and other concessions.

The BBC's political editor Laura Kuenssberg said the DUP had been "insistent" on getting more information about Sir Edward's role before it would agree to any deal.

She said the party was concerned that the former prime minister had been involved in secret talks with the IRA during the 1974 power-sharing executive, which collapsed after just seven months.

The DUP is also said to be seeking more money for Northern Ireland as part of any deal.

The party's leader Arlene Foster is due to meet Theresa May in London later on Tuesday.

Marsh, the world's largest insurance broker, is to cut 2,500 jobs, about 4% of its workforce.

The company said the cuts were necessary due to the "significant" impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the insurance industry.

Marsh said the job losses would be across all its businesses and geographies.

The company employs about 60,000 people in more than 130 countries.

Marsh's chief executive, Dan Glaser, said the pandemic had "accelerated pre-existing trends" in the insurance industry.

He said this had led to "significant reductions in demand" for some of Marsh's services.

Mr Glaser said the job cuts would help the company to reduce costs and adjust its business to the "new reality".

The company did not say how much it expected to save as a result of the job losses.

Brazil's lower house of Congress has approved a long-awaited reform of the country's bankruptcy laws.

The new law will make it easier for companies to restructure their debts and avoid bankruptcy.

It is seen as a key reform that will help boost Brazil's economy, which is struggling to recover from a deep recession.

The reform still needs to be approved by the Senate before it can become law.

Brazil's current bankruptcy laws are seen as outdated and too complicated, deterring companies from seeking debt restructuring and encouraging them to declare bankruptcy.

The new law is expected to help Brazil's economy by making it easier for companies to restructure their debts and avoid bankruptcy.

It is also seen as a key reform that will help attract foreign investment and boost Brazil's economy.

Howard attacks 'pay later' Budget

George Osborne's Budget is a "pay later" one which will not kick-start growth, the ex-chancellor has said.

Doubts about the Spending Review - which was announced on Wednesday - had already been raised by some Conservative MPs and economists.

Mr Osborne said his old friend was a "very competent chancellor" but the country needed "action now".

He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "This is a pay later Budget."

The BBC's Iain Watson said although Mr Osborne was not criticising individual measures in the Spending Review, his remarks were "significant" because he was a former chancellor.

"What George Osborne is saying is that this is not a Budget for growth," he said.

"He believes that the country needs action now in order to get the economy motoring again - he doesn't believe that this Budget really delivers that."

'Fiscal drag'

Mr Osborne, who was chancellor from 2010 to 2016, said the UK needed a "Budget for growth" and accused the government of being "behind the curve".

He said: "What the country needs, and this is the message I think from the business community, from many economists, is a Budget for growth, a Budget that recognises that we're now in a very different world, that we need to do more to get our economy moving.

"I don't think this Budget really delivers that. I think it's a very competent Budget from a very competent chancellor, but it's a pay later Budget."

He added: "We're now in a world where interest rates are very low, we're in a world where Brexit uncertainties are holding back investment, we're in a world where our productivity performance has been poor."

Mr Osborne said the main way the government could help boost growth would be through "fiscal drag" - using the tax system to put more money into people's pockets.

"It's a bit of a contradiction in terms but if you reduce the amount of tax that people are paying, that gives them more money in their pocket to spend and that helps to get the economy moving," he said.

The cost of studying at university is not a major factor in deciding whether to go, a poll suggests.

The YouGov survey of 2,049 people aged 18-24 found that just over a third (34%) said fees were a "very important" consideration.

But when asked what the most important factor was, the most popular response was the quality of the course (39%).

The poll also found that the majority of young people (61%) thought university was a good investment.

The findings come as the government prepares to announce plans to raise the cap on tuition fees in England to 9,000 a year.

The YouGov poll found that the most important factor in deciding whether to go to university was the quality of the course, followed by the cost of living and the cost of tuition fees.

When asked what the least important factor was, the most popular response was the cost of tuition fees, followed by the cost of living and the quality of the course.

The UK government could still regulate the internet despitearrecent court ruling, the culture secretary has said. Jeremy Wright said the government was "disappointed" with the judgment but respected it. The High Court ruled last week that the government could not block three gambling websites without parliamentary approval. Mr Wright said the government was considering appealing against the ruling. "We will now consider the detail of the judgment and whether to appeal it," he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show.

Responding to the ruling, Mr Wright said the government could not block gambling websites without parliamentary approval.

"We are disappointed with the judgment but we respect it," he said.

"It doesn't mean that we can't do anything about online harms, it simply means we can't do this particular thing in this particular way."

He said the government was looking at other ways to regulate the internet, including working with internet service providers (ISPs) and social media companies.

"I think there are other things we can do," he said.

"We can continue to work with the ISPs, we can continue to work with the social media companies, to try and ensure that the internet is a safe place."

The Christmas gadget season is upon us and one of the hottest items is the MP3 player.

These tiny devices can store and play hundreds of songs, making them the perfect stocking filler for music lovers.

The latest models come with all sorts of bells and whistles, including colour screens, photo viewers and even FM radios.

Prices start at around 30, but the sky's the limit for the more expensive models.

So, if you're looking for the perfect Christmas present for the music lover in your life, an MP3 player could be just the ticket.

Robbie Fowler's late equaliser rescued a point for Blackburn Rovers as they twice came from behind to draw 2-2 with Manchester City.

Fowler, who had earlier missed a penalty, slotted home after City had failed to clear a corner.

City had looked set to win after taking the lead through Nicolas Anelka's penalty and then retaking the lead through Shaun Wright-Phillips.

But Blackburn showed great character to twice hit back and Fowler's goal means they are now unbeaten in four games.

Keegan said: "I thought we were the better team for long periods but we didn't make the most of our possession.

"We gave away two poor goals. The first one was a penalty and the second one was just a poor bit of defending.

"But we showed great character to come back twice and I think a draw was a fair result in the end."

Media players could be forced to make it easier for people to find alternative sources of information, under plans being considered by the government.

The proposal is one of a number of options being looked at by ministers in an attempt to tackle the spread of "fake news".

Other ideas include making social media firms liable for the content on their platforms.

The government is also considering setting up a new regulator to oversee the media.

The plans are at an early stage and no decisions have been made, but the BBC understands the proposals will be discussed by ministers in the coming weeks.

The government is under pressure to act after a series of scandals involving the spread of false information online, including during the US presidential election.

There is also concern that the UK could be vulnerable to similar problems in the run-up to the next general election, scheduled for 2020.

Under the plans being considered, media players such as Facebook and Google could be required to sign up to a code of conduct that would make it easier for users to find alternative sources of information.

The code could include measures such as labelling stories that have been disputed by fact-checkers, or providing links to other stories on the same topic.

The government is also looking at the possibility of making social media firms liable for the content on their platforms, in the same way that publishers are currently liable for the content of their newspapers.

At present, social media firms are not legally responsible for the content on their platforms, but are required to remove material that is illegal under UK law.

The government is also considering setting up a new regulator to oversee the media, with the power to impose fines or issue "corrections" notices.

The regulator would be independent of government, but would have the power to investigate complaints and take action against media organisations that breach the code of conduct.

The proposals are being considered by a group of ministers, including Prime Minister Theresa May, Culture Secretary Karen Bradley and Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Secretary Matt Hancock.

A final decision is not expected to be made until after the local elections in May.

Turkey turns on the economic charm

The Turkish government is turning on the economic charm in an attempt to woo foreign investors.

The country's deputy prime minister said on Monday that Turkey wanted to be seen as a "safe haven" for investors.

His comments come as the Turkish economy is under pressure from a currency crisis and high inflation.

The government has been seeking to improve relations with the West and attract foreign investment.

Deputy Prime Minister Mehmet Simsek said the country was committed to democracy and rule of law.

"We are trying to do whatever is necessary to reassure investors that this is a stable and secure place to do business," he said.

"Turkey is an anchor of stability in a very challenging region."

Simsek said the government was working to improve the business environment and make it easier for foreign investors to do business in Turkey.

He also said the country was committed to reforms, including privatisations and deregulation.

"There is no question that the overall environment is more conducive to investment now," he said.

Turkey has been seeking to attract foreign investment to help boost its economy, which is facing a currency crisis and high inflation.

The government has been seeking to improve relations with the West and attract foreign investment.

last year, the Turkish government issued a series of economic reforms in an attempt to shore up the economy.

The reforms included deregulation, privatisation and tax cuts.

Turkey's economy is forecast to grow by around 4% this year, after expanding by 7.4% last year.

The world's nuclear watchdog is seeking new technology to help it detect and track nuclear materials.

The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) said the move was in response to "the evolving nuclear threat landscape".

It comes amid concerns that terrorist groups could try to build a nuclear device.

The IAEA said it was looking for "innovative approaches" to detecting nuclear and radiological materials.

"The IAEA's mandate is to help prevent nuclear terrorism," said IAEA Director General Yukiya Amano.

"This requires us to continuously improve our ability to detect and track nuclear and other radioactive materials that could be used in a nuclear weapon or radiological dispersal device."

The IAEA said it was looking for "portable and mobile systems" that could be used at short notice to detect nuclear and radiological materials "in a wide range of environments".

The deadline for submissions is 31 October.

A new world record has been set for the number of text messages sent in 24 hours.

More than 618 million text messages were sent on the Chinese New Year's Eve, according to the country's state-run news agency.

The previous record was set on Christmas Day in the UK, when more than 508 million texts were sent.

China has the world's biggest mobile phone market, with more than 1.3 billion subscribers.

In the aftermath of a disaster, text messages can be a lifeline for people trying to find loved ones or get information about what to do next.

That's why the American Red Cross has launched a new service that allows people to send text messages to the Red Cross to get help or information.

The service is called "Text to Connect" and it's available in English and Spanish.

To use the service, people can text the word "CONNECT" to 79922. They will then be asked to provide their name and location.

Once the Red Cross has that information, they will be able to provide assistance or connect the person to resources in their area.

The service is free, but standard text messaging rates may apply.

Media mogul Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is "the bully in the room" and its attempt to buy out broadcaster Sky is a "cynical ploy", the veteran journalist Andrew Neil has said.

In an impassioned attack on the media giant, the former Sunday Times editor and BBC presenter accused News Corp of a "statutory takeover" of Sky.

Speaking to the Leveson Inquiry into press ethics, he added that the Murdochs had a "stranglehold on British politics".

News Corporation wants to buy the 60% of Sky it does not already own.

The Murdoch family also controls the Sun, the Times and the Sunday Times newspapers.

'Same old story'

In his evidence to the inquiry, Andrew Neil said: "I think it's the same old story with the Murdochs. They're a law unto themselves.

"They believe that the ends always justify the means and they believe they're answerable to no-one except themselves."

He added: "I think that they are the bully in the room."

Referring to the Murdochs' appearance before the inquiry last month, he said: "I think they treated this inquiry with contempt.

"They came here, they read out prepared statements and then they refused to answer any substantive questions.

"I think that reflects their attitude to the whole process."

Interest rates in the UK have been held at 4.75% by the Bank of England.

It is the fourth month in a row that rates have remained unchanged.

The BoE said the economy had slowed slightly in the past few months, but was still growing at a rate "slightly above" its long-term average.

Inflation remains above the government's 2% target, at 2.3% in May, although the BoE said it expected it to fall back to target over the "coming months".

Howl's Moving Castle has had a big impact on Japan's box office.

The latest film from Miyazaki Hayao, one of the country's most popular directors, has taken $171m (93m) since its release in June.

His previous film, Spirited Away, was the most successful film in Japanese history, taking $330m (183m) in 2001.

Howl's Moving Castle has been doing so well that it has helped to reverse a decline in box office receipts.

In the first half of 2004, cinemas in Japan took $1.24bn (683m), a fall of 8.4% on the same period last year.

But the release of Howl's Moving Castle has seen a significant increase in the number of people going to the cinema.

In the two weeks after its release, the film took $47m (25.8m), and in the following week, it was still number one at the box office, taking $17m (9.3m).

This is the first time that a film has topped the box office for three weeks in a row since Titanic in 1998.

Labour's Ed Miliband has urged voters in the North East to back his party in next week's European elections.

The Labour leader was in Sunderland, where he said a strong Labour vote would send a message to the government about its handling of the economy.

He also pledged to stand up for workers' rights and the NHS, and accused the Conservatives of wanting to take the UK out of the EU.

The North East is one of nine English regions electing MEPs on 22 May.

The row over David Blunkett's resignation should now end, Tony Blair has said.

The prime minister was speaking after a weekend of revelations about the home secretary's private life.

Mr Blunkett quit on Friday after it emerged he had fast-tracked a visa application for his former lover's nanny.

Mr Blair said the home secretary had been "forced out of office" and that the issue should now be dropped.

'Private life'

In an interview with BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Blair said: "I think the important thing now is that we just draw a line under this, that we recognise that David Blunkett has been an excellent home secretary.

"He's done a great job in difficult circumstances and we should now just leave him to get on with his private life."

Mr Blair said he had not spoken to Mr Blunkett since his resignation.

"I think the important thing is that we just recognise that David Blunkett has been an excellent home secretary"



Tony Blair

Asked whether he would like to, he replied: "Of course, but I think the important thing is that we just recognise that David Blunkett has been an excellent home secretary.

"He's done a great job in difficult circumstances and we should now just leave him to get on with his private life."

'Great sadness'

The prime minister said he had not seen the full details of the allegations against Mr Blunkett.

"I've seen the headlines, I haven't seen the detail of it," he said.

"I think it's a great sadness that this has happened to him.

"But I think the important thing now is that we just draw a line under this, that we recognise that David Blunkett has been an excellent home secretary."

The prime minister has apologised to three people who were jailed for their part in the final days of the Gaddafi regime in Libya.

In a letter to Michael Purcell, David disabled and Abdul Hakim Bilal, Theresa May said she was "very sorry" for the "appalling ordeal" they had suffered.

The three men were part of a group of nineSent to Libya in 2014 to support the British embassy during the country's political transition.

They were detained in October that year on suspicion of spying and appeared in court in Tripoli the following month.

Mr Purcell and Mr Dann were sentenced to life in prison, while Mr Bilal was jailed for 12 years.

The men were released in March this year and returned to the UK.

In her letter, Mrs May said the UK government "did not do enough" to protect them.

"I am deeply disappointed that we were not able to do more to secure your release sooner," she said.

"The UK government will continue to provide all the support you need as you rebuild your lives."

Ivan Lendl believes Jamie Murray made the right decision to return to the Davis Cup fold. The world number five had not played for Great Britain in eight years but is in Lendl's squad for next month's World Group tie with Japan in Birmingham.

The 32-year-old could team up with older brother Andy in the doubles and Lendl is glad he is back.

"It is obviously a big coup for us," Lendl told BBC Sport.

"Jamie is a great team player, a great doubles player and I am sure the crowd will enjoy seeing him play. I am really happy he decided to come back."

 Murray last played in the Davis Cup in 2005 but has been persuaded to return by Lendl and captain Leon Smith.

The Scot was part of the team that lost to Netherlands in the Europe/Africa Zone Group I second round in February but was not selected for the must-win tie with Luxembourg in July.

"I had a chat with Leon and Jamie after Wimbledon this year and we talked about the idea of him coming back," Lendl said.

"We all decided it was the right thing to do. I believe tennis is a team sport and it is important for the players to understand that.

"When you put on the GB Davis Cup shirt, it is different. It is representing your country and that is a piece of clothing that not many people get to wear."

Murray has not played since Wimbledon but Lendl believes he will be ready for the clash with Japan, which starts on 4 September.

"He has had some good practice sessions with Andy and I am sure he will be fine," Lendl added.

"It is not like he has had six weeks off - he played until Wimbledon and then had a few weeks off. He has been practising and is fresh and I am sure he will be ready to go."

British Olympic hopeful Johnson edges out rival Sotherton

Dame Kelly Holmes' training partner, Lisa Dobriskey, has been ruled out of the Commonwealth Games after suffering an Achilles injury.

The 27-year-old, who won 1500m silver at the 2006 Commonwealth Games, was due to compete in Delhi but has been forced to withdraw.

"It is with great disappointment that I have to announce my withdrawal from the Commonwealth Games," Dobriskey said.

"I have been struggling with an Achilles injury for some time and after seeking expert medical advice, it has been decided that I need to take an extended break from training and racing."

Dobriskey, who is based in Loughborough, added: "I would like to wish the rest of the team all the very best of luck in Delhi."

The news is a further blow to the British team, who are already without world and European 800m champion Jenny Meadows and world indoor 1500m silver medallist Laura Weightman.

Little Britain has been named the best comedy of the 21st century in a poll of industry experts.

The show, created by Matt Lucas and David Walliams, topped a Radio Times poll of 100 comedy insiders, including writers, directors, producers and performers.

It was followed by The Office, Father Ted, The Thick of It and Peep Show in the top five.

Little Britain also came top of a separate poll of Radio Times readers, with The Office in second place.

The show, which ran for three series between 2003 and 2005, was praised by those polled for its "sharp writing" and "outrageous" characters.

Speaking to the Radio Times, Walliams said: "We are thrilled and honoured that Little Britain has been voted the best comedy of the 21st century.

"We are very proud of the show and its place in British culture."

Lucas added: "It's a real privilege to be involved in something that has made so many people laugh."

The show, which was first broadcast on BBC Three, starred Lucas and Walliams as a host of eccentric characters, including Vicky Pollard, Marjorie Dawes and Daffyd Thomas.

It won two Baftas and a British Comedy Award during its run.

The US Federal Aviation Administration says it will investigate claims that airlines are deliberately creating chaos at US airports.

Airlines for America, an industry group, has accused the FAA of "mismanagement" of the air traffic system.

It says the agency's decision to use a new flight control system has caused widespread delays.

The FAA says the new system will improve safety and efficiency in the long run.

The disagreement between the FAA and the airline industry over the new flight control system came to a head on Friday, when Airlines for America filed a lawsuit against the agency.

In the lawsuit, the airline group accused the FAA of "mismanagement" of the air traffic system, and said the agency's decision to use the new system had caused widespread delays.

The FAA has denied the claims, saying that the new system will improve safety and efficiency in the long run.

Amlie Mauresmo opened her Los Angeles campaign with a 6-3 6-2 victory over Marta Domachowska.

The top seed from France broke the Pole three times in the first set and twice more in the second to progress in just over an hour.

Mauresmo will face either American Jill Craybas or qualifier Alina Jidkova in the second round.

The second seed in Los Angeles, Svetlana Kuznetsova, also progressed with a 6-3 6-2 win over fellow Russian Vera Dushevina.

Missing millions

China is investigating reports that more than $1bn has gone missing from a state-run bank.

The money is said to have vanished from the Agricultural Bank of China's (ABC) operations in the eastern city of Suzhou.

The case is the latest in a string of financial scandals to hit the country.

In another development, the central bank has announced it is investigating a subsidiary of one of China's biggest banks over possible breaches of money-lending rules.

The ABC case was first reported by the state-run China News Service, which quoted unnamed sources.

It said the lender had set up a special team to look into the matter.

The report did not say how the money went missing or when, and the bank has yet to comment.

But the case will increase suspicion about the health of China's banking system, analysts say.

The system is saddled with billions of dollars of non-performing loans, and a number of officials have been accused of corruption in recent years.

Last month, the head of ABC's Hubei province branch was fired and placed under investigation for "serious violation of discipline".

And in May, the chairman of another state-run bank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), was placed under investigation for "serious violations of discipline".

The latest case comes as China's central bank announced an investigation into Ping An Bank, a subsidiary of insurer Ping An Insurance.

The central bank said it was looking into possible breaches of rules on lending to individuals and small businesses.

Ping An said it was cooperating with the investigation.

Piero Della Francesca, the great Renaissance artist, died 500 years ago this month.

He was born in the town of Sansepolcro in Tuscany and is best known for his paintings of the Battle of Anghiari and the legendary meeting of 386 AD between Emperor Constantine and Pope Sylvester.

But Della Francesca was also an inventor, a cartographer and a mathematician.

And, it turns out, a rugby fan.

In 1472, he painted a fresco of a rugby match in the Palazzo Ducale in Urbino.

It shows two teams of seven players, two of whom have the ball, and a referee.

The game looks surprisingly like modern rugby, with players passing the ball and tackling each other.

However, there are some key differences.

For one thing, the players are all wearing armour.

And, instead of a try, the team that scores the most goals wins the match.

The painting is called The Legend of Good and Bad Government, and it was meant to be a political allegory.

But it's also a reminder that rugby has a long and rich history.

It's a game that has been played for centuries, in many different cultures.

And it's a game that continues to evolve.

Who knows what the game will look like in another 500 years?

The Conservatives have pledged to offer free sports lessons to every primary school child in England if they win the general election.

The party said the move would cost 320m a year and would reverse recent cuts to school sports budgets.

The Tories also announced a new target to get two million more adults active by 2025.

Labour said the plans did not go far enough, while the Lib Dems said they were a "drop in the ocean".

The Conservatives said their plans would see all primary school children in England receive two hours of PE a week, with a qualified teacher leading the lessons.

The party said the money for the scheme would come from the 10bn a year NHS funding pledge, as well as from saving money on school buildings and " inefficient" spending on sports facilities.

The Tories said their plans would also see a new target of getting two million more adults active by 2025, although they did not detail how this would be achieved.

The party said it would also invest 100m in grassroots sport, as well as setting up a 10m fund to support elite athletes.

Speaking at the launch of the plans, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said: " too many people are missing out on the life-changing benefits of sport.

"That is why we are making such a big commitment to get more people, especially young people, doing more sport and physical activity."

Conservative Party chairman James Cleverly said the plans would help to create a "fitter, healthier nation".

"We are absolutely committed to levelling up opportunity across the country and that means making sure everyone has the chance to get active, regardless of their background," he said.

Labour's shadow sports minister Alison McGovern said the Conservatives' plans did not go far enough.

"The Tories have cut school sports budgets by 453m since 2015 - this promise does not make up for that," she said.

"Labour will go further by guaranteeing that every primary child will have at least 60 minutes of PE and active play every day, and we will invest 1.3bn a year in school sports."

Lib Dem MP Layla Moran, the party's spokesperson on sport, said the Conservatives' plans were a "drop in the ocean".

"This is a desperate attempt by the Conservatives to try and distract from their chaotic handling of Brexit which has seen investment in areas like sport completely neglected," she said.

Doncaster picked up a deserved point at high-flying Hereford with a 1-1 draw.

The visitors took the lead in the 14th minute when Billy Sharp bundled the ball home from close range after good work by James Hayter.

But the home side equalised against the run of play on the half-hour when Graham Turner's side failed to clear a corner and Dean Beckwith volleyed home at the far post.

Doncaster nearly regained the lead soon afterwards but John Marquis shot wide when well placed.

The home side then began to apply some pressure of their own and they should have gone in front 10 minutes before the break when Sharp burst through but he shot straight at Phil Barnes in the Doncaster goal.

After the break, Doncaster had the better of the early exchanges and went close to retaking the lead when Sharp's volley was well saved by home keeper Wayne Brown.

At the other end, Barnes produced a fine save to keep out Michael Rankine's powerful header.

Hereford continued to press forward in search of a winner but they were unable to find a way past a resolute Doncaster defence and the game ended in a deserved draw.

Tom Hanks is to star in a new film about the life of Leonardo da Vinci.

The upcoming film will be directed by Ron Howard and is based on a script by Akiva Goldsman, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

Hanks will play the titular role in the untitled film, which will focus on the Italian artist and inventor's life.

The film will be produced by Imagine Entertainment, which is run by Brian Grazer and Ron Howard.

Hanks and Howard previously worked together on the films "Apollo 13" and "A Beautiful Mind".

"I am thrilled to be reuniting with my friend Tom Hanks to bring the incredible story of Leonardo da Vinci to the screen," Howard said in a statement.

"He was the ultimate Renaissance man, a genius who epitomised the spirit of that great era of discovery, art and exploration. Tom will bring all the dimensions of Leonardo to life."

Hanks added: "Leonardo da Vinci was an extraordinary man who touched so many disciplines during his lifetime. I am looking forward to bringing that type of multifaceted character to the screen."

The film is set to begin production in early 2019.

"Italy aim to rattle England"

Italy have been boosted by the return of key midfielder Marco Verratti ahead of their World Cup qualifier against England.

The Paris Saint-Germain player missed the Azzurri's last two games with a thigh injury but has been included in Gian Piero Ventura's 23-man squad.

Captain Gianluigi Buffon, 38, is set to win his 173rd cap, equalling Paolo Maldini's record for an outfield player.

Andrea Belotti, who has scored 12 goals in 12 Serie A appearances this season, is also in the squad.

England are top of Group F with 10 points from four games, while Italy are second on eight.

The winner of Wednesday's match at Wembley will take a big step towards qualifying for the 2018 World Cup in Russia.

England boss Gareth Southgate has called on his players to show "courage" and "ambition" against the 2006 world champions.

"It'll be a great test for us. They're a very experienced team, with some world-class players," he said.

"But we want to make Wembley a tough place for opponents to come. We're looking forward to the challenge."

Southgate has hinted he could make changes to his side following Saturday's 2-0 win over Malta, with Jack Wilshere and Jesse Lingard among those pushing for starting roles.

Scotland's hopes of a first win in the Six Nations since 2010 have been dealt a blow with the news that winger Tommy Seymour will miss the rest of the tournament.

The Glasgow player suffered a hamstring injury in training and will play no further part in the championship.

Seymour, 27, has scored five tries in 18 Tests for Scotland.

Head coach Vern Cotter said: "It is disappointing for Tommy and for the team."

Scotland are currently bottom of the Six Nations table after two defeats, against England and Wales.

They host France at Murrayfield on Sunday.

Ryan Giggs has been appointed as the new manager of Wales on a four-year contract.

The 44-year-old succeeds Chris Coleman, who left to take charge of Sunderland in November.

Giggs is the most decorated player in Welsh football history, winning 64 caps and scoring 12 goals.

He takes over a Wales side that failed to qualify for the 2018 World Cup, finishing third in their qualifying group behind Republic of Ireland and group winners Serbia.

"I am thrilled and honoured to be given the responsibility of managing the Wales national team," Giggs said in a statement.

"I know there is huge potential within the squad and I'm looking forward to working with them and helping them realise their dreams of playing at a major tournament."

Wales have not qualified for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup.

Giggs played in the team that reached the semi-finals of the European Championship in 2016, before losing to eventual winners Portugal.

He will officially begin his Wales managerial reign on Monday, with his first game in charge against the Republic of Ireland in Dublin on 6 February.

The government has defended its decision to spend 6m on a poster campaign urging people to get a flu jab.

The campaign, which starts on Monday, features the slogan "Flu - don't let it ruin your Christmas".

Health Secretary Alan Milburn said the campaign was "targeted" and "cost-effective".

But the Conservatives said the government was "wasting" money on the campaign and should be concentrating on other health priorities.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn said the campaign was "targeted" and "cost-effective".

But the Conservatives said the government was "wasting" money on the campaign and should be concentrating on other health priorities.

Mr Milburn said the campaign was aimed at people in "at-risk" groups, such as the elderly and people with chronic illnesses.

He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "We are targeting the campaign very specifically at those people who are most at risk from the effects of flu.

"We know that if we can persuade more people in those at-risk groups to have the jab, we can save lives."

Mr Milburn said the government had "doubled" the number of people vaccinated against flu since 1997 and wanted to increase that figure further.

"We think this is a cost-effective way of doing that," he said.

But shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox said the government should be concentrating on other health priorities, such as reducing waiting times for operations.

"The government is wasting 6m on a poster campaign telling people something they already know - that they should get a flu jab," he said.

"This money would be better spent on actually providing the flu vaccine for those who need it."

Isinbayeva heads for Birmingham

The world's best pole vaulter, Yelena Isinbayeva, will compete in the Birmingham Games on Sunday.

The Russian, who has held the world record since 2003, will be up against American Stacy Dragila, the Olympic champion.

Isinbayeva has been in outstanding form this season, clearing 5.01m in Paris last month.

That performance took her past Dragila's best of 4.91m and the American will be keen to regain the world record in Birmingham.

The meeting will also feature Britain's best hope for a medal, Steve Lewis, in the men's 400m hurdles.

JP Morgan has become the first major US bank to acknowledge its link to slavery.

In a report commissioned by the firm, historians found that at least some of the bank's 19th-century predecessors had been involved in financing the slave trade.

The report found that two of JP Morgan's key 19th-centuries banks had worked with slave-owning plantations.

It also found that the firm'sModern day charitable foundation was funded by profits from slavery.

"This was a shameful period in our nation's history, and one that we are not proud of," JP Morgan said in a statement.

"We hope that by acknowledging these facts, we can help to promote a more honest and candid dialogue about this period of our country's history."

JP Morgan is not the first major corporation to face up to its slave-owning past.

In 2005, the insurance giant AIG admitted that it had benefited from the slave trade.

And last year, the British bank Barclays announced that it would make a public apology for its involvement in the slave trade.

Yeading will face Newcastle in the FA Cup after the Magpies beat Blackburn on Tuesday.

The non-league side from west London beat Gillingham in a dramatic penalty shootout in the first round on Sunday.

Newcastle, who are struggling in the Premier League, needed a late goal from substitute Obafemi Martins to see off Blackburn.

The tie will be played at St James' Park on the weekend of 3-4 December.

President Kennedy has acknowledged that the American people must have faith in their government's abilities if it is to succeed in taxation.

In a televised address, he said progress had been made in tax collection but more needed to be done.

"The time has come to recognize that the American people must have confidence in the fairness of our tax system," he said.

"This can only be accomplished by simplifying the tax laws and by making certain that the Internal Revenue Service [IRS] is as efficient and economical as possible."

The president said that the IRS must be seen to be "impartial and just" in its dealings with taxpayers.

"No organisation can function without the respect and trust of the people it serves," he said.

"The American people must have faith in their government's abilities if it is to succeed. And that faith must be based on confidence in the government's fairness."

A US computer expert has unveiled a prototype for a sub-$100 PC which he says could transform access to the internet in the developing world.

Nicholas Negroponte, founder of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Lab, showed off the machine at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

The so-called "$100 laptop" is designed for children in poor countries and will be powered by a hand-crank.

Mr Negroponte said he hoped to have the first machines ready by the end of the year.

"One Laptop per Child is an idea to provide every child in the world access to knowledge and learning," he told the BBC News website.

"It's a computer that's designed for children, it's very rugged, it has a hand-crank so you don't need electricity, it has a solar cell so it can recharge in sunlight."

The machine, which is about the size of a small textbook, will be able to connect to the internet via a wireless network.

It will also have a built-in webcam and microphone so that children can communicate with each other.

The laptops will run on a new operating system, which is being developed by a team led by One Laptop per Child's chief technology officer, Mary Lou Jepsen.

Ms Jepsen said the machine would be "hackable" so that children could customise it to their own needs.

"It's really important that the laptops are something that the kids themselves can make their own and personalise," she said.

"We're going to have a programming interface so that any kid who wants to can write new software for the machine."

The laptops will be sold to governments, which will then distribute them to schools.

Mr Negroponte said he hoped to have the first machines ready by the end of the year, and to have produced five million of them by 2007.

Owen set for skipper role

England striker Michael Owen is set to be named as the new captain of Liverpool.

The 23-year-old is expected to be confirmed as the Reds' skipper when manager Gerard Houllier unveils his squad for the new season on Friday.

Owen, who has scored more than 100 goals for Liverpool, will take over the captaincy from Sami Hyypia.

Houllier is also expected to name a new vice-captain, with Jamie Carragher and Dietmar Hamann the leading contenders.

Owen's appointment as captain is likely to see him handed a new long-term contract by the Anfield club.

He has two years left on his current deal, but Liverpool are keen to tie him down to a new contract which would keep him at the club until 2007.

India is aiming to become a global construction powerhouse, with the development of a new $10bn investment fund.

The fund will be used to finance infrastructure projects in India and abroad.

The move is part of a wider push by the Indian government to boost the country's construction sector.

India's construction industry is currently worth around $126bn, and is expected to grow to $1trn by 2025.

Construction is a key driver of economic growth in India, and the government is hoping that the new fund will help the country to compete with China and other global construction giants.

The fund is being launched by the India Infrastructure Finance Company (IIFCL), and will be backed by the Indian government and a consortium of banks.

It is hoped that the fund will help to finance a range of infrastructure projects, including roads, bridges, railways, and power plants.

The IIFCL has already committed $2bn to the fund, and it is hoped that the remaining $8bn will be raised from private investors.

The launch of the fund comes as the Indian government is seeking to attract $100bn of investment into the country's infrastructure sector.

The government has also launched a new $1.5bn infrastructure fund, which will be used to finance projects in the transport, energy, and urban development sectors.

Search engines are closing in on their users - quite literally.

Google and Microsoft's search sites are both testing new features that allow searchers to find out information about nearby businesses and services.

The new services follow in the footsteps of location-based social networks such as Foursquare and Gowalla, which have proved popular with mobile phone users.

Both Google and Microsoft are hopin British mobile phone users will increasingly use their search engines to find local information.

Google's service, called "Local Search", is currently available in the US and UK, and lets users find businesses and services near their current location.

The service uses the location of the user's mobile phone to provide results, and also provides directions and maps.

Microsoft's service, called "Local Scout", is currently available in the US and is being tested in the UK.

It provides results based on the user's current location, and also includes reviews and ratings from other users.

The new services are part of a trend towards so-called "local search", which is seen as a key area of growth for search engines.

It is also an important new revenue stream for mobile phone operators, who are keen to sell location-based services to their customers.

The two main parties in the UK have pledged to freeze council tax if they win the next general election.

The Conservatives say they will freeze council tax for two years if they form the next government.

Labour say they will give councils the power to freeze council tax for a year.

The Lib Dems have not announced a specific policy on council tax, but say they will give councils "more power" to set their own budgets.

The SNP in Scotland have already announced a council tax freeze for the whole of the next Scottish Parliament.

Little Britain is in the running for a prestigious television award.

The show has been nominated for the Bafta for best comedy programme.

It is up against The Office, I'm Alan Partridge, Father Ted and The Kumars at No 42.

The Baftas will be presented at a ceremony in London on May 12.

Verizon 'seals takeover of MCI'

Verizon Communications has completed its $8.4bn (4.6bn) takeover of MCI, creating the second-largest US telecoms group.

The deal, which was first announced in February, will see MCI shareholders receive 0.605 Verizon shares for each MCI share they own.

The combined group will have about $90bn in annual revenues and more than 200 million customers.

The takeover is the latest in a string of consolidation deals in the telecoms sector.

Last year, Verizon bought long-distance operator AT&T Wireless for $28bn.

Sprint is currently in the process of acquiring Nextel for $35bn.

The MCI deal will give Verizon a stronger presence in the business market, where it has lagged behind its rivals.

MCI's network covers 200 countries and serves about 60% of Fortune 500 companies.

The deal is also expected to help Verizon cut costs by about $18bn over the next three years.

The leader of the UK's Conservative Party has quit his legal position in protest at the government's handling of the Brexit negotiations.

In a letter to the prime minister, Andrea Leadsom said she could not support the government's approach to the talks.

She said she was resigning with "deep regret" and would continue to support Theresa May from the backbenches.

The move comes as the government is trying to reach a deal with the European Union on the UK's exit from the bloc.

Mrs Leadsom, who was one of the leading Brexiteers in the 2016 referendum campaign, has been critical of the government's approach to the talks in recent weeks.

In her letter, she said she no longer believed that the UK's negotiating strategy would deliver a good deal for the country.

"I have been demonstrating my support for the Prime Minister and her team in these negotiations but it has become clear to me that their approach will not deliver on the Brexit people voted for and it is time for me to leave the Cabinet," Mrs Leadsom wrote.

"I fully respect the Prime Minister and I have enjoyed working with her. I am sorry that it has come to this and I hope you will forgive me."

Mrs May thanked Mrs Leadsom for her "dedication and service" and said she was "sorry" to see her go.

The move comes as the government is trying to reach a deal with the European Union on the UK's exit from the bloc.

Mrs Leadsom, who was one of the leading Brexiteers in the 2016 referendum campaign, has been critical of the government's approach to the talks in recent weeks.

In her letter, she said she no longer believed that the UK's negotiating strategy would deliver a good deal for the country.

"I have been demonstrating my support for the Prime Minister and her team in these negotiations but it has become clear to me that their approach will not deliver on the Brexit people voted for and it is time for me to leave the Cabinet," Mrs Leadsom wrote.

"I fully respect the Prime Minister and I have enjoyed working with her. I am sorry that it has come to this and I hope you will forgive me."

Mrs May thanked Mrs Leadsom for her "dedication and service" and said she was "sorry" to see her go.

Conservative Party leader David Cameron has given his backing to the government's plans for ID cards.

He told the BBC the scheme would help tackle illegal immigration and terrorism and give people "peace of mind".

The government says the cards, which will cost 30 each, will help to cut crime and fraud. But critics say they are a waste of money and an infringement of civil liberties.

Ministers want the first cards to be issued to foreign nationals from 2009 and to all UK residents by 2017.

'Peace of mind'

Speaking on BBC One's Sunday AM programme, Mr Cameron said: "I think ID cards are a good idea.

"I think they will help us tackle things like illegal immigration, I think they will help us make sure that people entitled to free NHS treatment actually get it, and I think they will give people a bit more peace of mind."

He added that the cards should not be compulsory, but people should be "encouraged" to take one up.

"I think it is perfectly possible to have a voluntary system which encourages people to take up ID cards and I think that is the way we should go about it," he said.

'Dangerous precedent'

The government says the cards will cost 5.4bn to set up and 585m a year to run.

But the Conservatives say the scheme is "wasteful" and have pledged to scrap it if they win power.

Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Nick Clegg said the cards were a "dangerous precedent".

"The government is sleepwalking towards a surveillance society," he said.

"The introduction of compulsory ID cards, linked to a central database, will do nothing to improve our security while setting a dangerous precedent for the state to intrude ever further into our private lives."

A decade ago on 2 March, Jerry Yang and David Filo, two graduate students at Stanford University, published a directory of their favourite websites. 

The guide was simple - just a list of links arranged in categories - but it rapidly became popular, and within months they had produced a second, bigger version. 

By the end of the year, the two Californians had given up their studies to concentrate on developing the directory, which they christened Yahoo! - an acronym for "Yet Another Hierarchical Officious Oracle".

The early years were rocky, as the pair had trouble convincing advertisers to support their venture. 

But in 1996, they struck a deal with a search engine called AltaVista, which provided the bulk of Yahoo!'s traffic and helped it to become profitable.

Yahoo! was one of the first companies to exploiting the commercial potential of the web, and its success helped to fuel the dotcom boom of the late 1990s. 

It was floated on the stock market in 1996, and by the end of the year its share price had risen by nearly three hundred percent. 

The company now employs more than 12,000 people, and according to web traffic measurement firm Alexa, it is the fifth most popular website in the world.

Baghdad Blogger on big screen

The story of a Baghdad blogger is being made into a Hollywood film.

The film, titled "The Baghdad Blogger", will tell the story of Salam Pax, who wrote a blog during the US-led invasion of Iraq in 2003.

Pax, whose real name is Salam al-Janabi, became a voice of the Iraqi people during the war.

He has since moved to the UK and now works as a journalist.

The film will be directed by Paul Greengrass, who also directed the 2006 film "United 93".

The film is being produced by Scott Rudin, who has also produced films such as "The Social Network" and "No Country for Old Men".

Director Nair's Vanity project

A film-maker who has been criticised for her "vanity project" says she is not concerned about the negative reviews.

Mira Nair's new film The Reluctant Fundamentalist, which stars Riz Ahmed and Kate Hudson, has been panned by critics.

But Nair told the BBC she was more concerned about the film'sBox Office performance.

"I make films from the heart and I don't really care about the chattering classes," she said.

"What I care about is if somebody who doesn't have a lot of money goes to the cinema and buys a ticket, and if they like my film."

The Reluctant Fundamentalist is based on the best-selling novel by Mohsin Hamid and tells the story of a Pakistani man working on Wall Street who begins to question his American dream.

It has been nominated for best film at this year's Baftas, but has received mixed reviews from critics.

The Guardian's Peter Bradshaw called it a "vanity project" for Nair, while the Daily Telegraph's Tim Robey said it was "a film of ideas, rather than emotions".

But Nair said she was not concerned by the criticism.

"I don't really care about the chattering classes," she said.

"What I care about is if somebody who doesn't have a lot of money goes to the cinema and buys a ticket, and if they like my film."

The film-maker also said she believed it was important to tell stories about "different cultures and different worlds".

"I think it's very important in this day and age that we have empathy and understanding for each other," she said.

"I think cinema can help with that, and I'm very proud of this film."

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger says his side were not good enough in the first half as they were held to a 1-1 draw at Newcastle.

The Gunners had the better of the second half and took the lead when Mesut Ozil's deflected shot wrong-footed Rob Elliot.

But Newcastle equalised late on as Olivier Giroud's header was turned in by substitute Mikel Merino.

"We were not at the races in the first half and we paid for it in the second," Wenger told BBC Sport.

"We had a good reaction in the second half and should have won the game. It is frustrating."

Newcastle had the better of the first half and took the lead in the 29th minute when Joselu converted Matt Ritchie's cross from close range.

Arsenal improved after the break and were rewarded when Ozil's shot took a big deflection off Newcastle defender Florian Lejeune and wrong-footed Elliot in the 76th minute.

But Newcastle snatched a late equaliser as Giroud's header from a corner was turned in by Merino.

It was a deserved point for Newcastle, who are now unbeaten in their last three games, while Arsenal's unbeaten run extends to eight games in all competitions.

There's a new lease of life for the Commodore computer brand, with two new models unveiled this week.

The C64x is a full-size desktop PC, while the C128 mini is a miniature version of the original Commodore 128.

Both systems are based on modern x86-64 hardware and run a version of the Linux operating system.

The C64x is being billed as a "multimedia PC" and comes with a DVD drive, Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connectivity, a 1TB hard drive, and an Intel Core i7 processor.

It also includes a full-size keyboard with a numeric keypad, and a replica of the original Commodore 64's joystick.

The core64 mini is a more compact version of the C64x, measuring just 16cm square. It comes with a DVD drive, Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connectivity, a 500GB hard drive, and an Intel Core i5 processor.

Both systems come with a selection of pre-installed games and applications, including the LibreOffice productivity suite, the Thunderbird email client, and the Firefox web browser.

The C64x is available to order now, priced at $899, while the C128 mini will be available from December, priced at $599.

Sylvester Stallone has been evicted from the Big Brother house.

The Hollywood actor had been one of the favourites to win the reality TV show, but he was voted out by the public on Friday night.

Stallone had been nominated for eviction by his fellow housemates earlier in the week.

He is the second celebrity to be voted out of the house, after American reality TV star Farrah Abraham was evicted on the show's launch night.

Stallone's eviction means that there are now just 11 celebrities remaining in the house.

It has been announced that former WWE star Brizzel will be running the UK arm of the American AAA wrestling organisation.

Brizzel, real name Brandon Lee, quit WWE in December and has been linked with a move to AAA since then.

AAA is one of the biggest wrestling promotions in the world and its UK branch will be based in Sheffield.

Brizzel will be in charge of training and booking talent for the UK shows, which are set to start later this year.

Speaking about his new role, Brizzel said: "I'm really excited to be a part of AAA and to help grow the brand in the UK."

 AAA president Dorian Roldan added: "Brizzel is a huge name in the wrestling world and we are delighted to have him on board to help launch AAA in the UK."

The Osbournes, MTV's hugely popular reality show featuring the dysfunctional family of rock singer Ozzy, is to end after four seasons.

MTV said on Wednesday that the final episode would air in the United States on 15 March.

The less-than-wholesome Osbournes were catapulted to fame in 2002 and their every move - from arguments to toilet habits - was watched by millions around the world.

But in recent years interest in the show has dwindled and the latest season was seen by just two million viewers.

"The Osbournes have been an incredibly important part of MTV over the past few years," said Van Toffler, president of MTV Networks.

"When they debuted, they took reality television to a whole new level - showcasing a celebrity family like never before," he added.

"Although we're saying goodbye to the series, the Osbourne family will always be part of the MTV family."

Ozzy, wife Sharon and their two children - Jack and Kelly - shot to stardom with their show, which documented their home life in Beverly Hills.

But after hitting the airwaves in 2002, the series lost some of its appeal as the stars became more accustomed to their newfound fame.

Ozzy, Sharon and Jack Osbourne are now set to star in a new reality series called The Osbournes Reloaded, which will see the family travelling the US and staging various challenges.

It will air on the Fox network in the Spring.
